description: The Coca-Cola Company said today that it would reinvest in South Africa after a seven-year absence because of anti-apartheid economic sanctions.

title: Pier I Imports Inc.(PIR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.Pier 1 Imports said that results for the latest quarter do not include the operations of 50 stores scheduled to close this fiscal year.

title: Redskins Deal for Linebacker
description: The Washington Redskins yesterday acquired linebacker TYRONNE STOWE in a trade with the Arizona Cardinals for an undisclosed draft choice. The 6-foot-2-inch, 250-pound Stowe led the Cardinals in tackles last year with a career-high 119, after finishing second on the team with 104 tackles in 1992. He has started 15 games in each of the past two seasons. (AP)

title: Empire Ex-Chief Sues Insurance Company
description: Albert A. Cardone, the former chief executive of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, is suing the insurance giant and its board of directors for more than $120 million, claiming they cheated him of his employee benefits and defamed him.

title: Elizabeth Paepcke, 91, a Force In Turning Aspen Into a Resort
description: Elizabeth Nitze Paepcke, who played a central role in transforming Aspen, Colo., from a largely abandoned 19th-century mining town into a winter resort, died on Wednesday at her home in Aspen. She was 91.

title: Classic Matchup, Hottest Ticket
description: It is unquestionably the marquee game of the early stages of the World Cup. It is the game for the bragging rights of a megalopolis with the largest ethnic populations in the country. It is Italy against Ireland Saturday on natural grass atop artificial turf at Giants Stadium.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Reuters yesterday about the release of some Palestinian prisoners referred incorrectly to Nahal Oz, the border point to which they were delivered by Israel. It is in Israel, not in the Gaza Strip.

title: Bronx Teen-Ager Drowns, Leaving Many Questions
description: New York City school officials and police and medical investigators in Pennsylvania were trying yesterday to determine how a year-end school outing to an amusement park near Allentown ended in the drowning of a Bronx teen-ager.

title: Williams Holding a Spot for Mansell
description: The Williams team appeared to leave open the possibility yesterday that NIGEL MANSELL could still return to Formula One in next month's French Grand Prix. The team released a statement from its headquarters in Didcot, England, saying no announcement on its driver lineup for the July 3 race at Magny-Cours would be made until the week of the race. Mansell won the Formula One title with Williams in 1992, then moved to the Indy-car circuit where he won the championship with Newman-Haas last season. This year, however, Mansell has yet to win a race. (AP)

title: Rockets Can't Find Basket In the 4th
description: The Rockets preferred to emphasize the good news, that they were returning to Houston two home-court victories from a National Basketball Association championship. They had earned a seventh game at home in the Summit, and now they would make use of it.

title: Public & Private; Fall From The Nest
description: The cardinals were in the sun room downstairs, battling the deceptive transparency of the windows. They were a matched pair, his and her, with the air of belonging together and being there for a purpose. The purpose was on the floor, a chick with the rheumy rolling eye and bony neck of an old man. The door had been left open for the dog, and the baby had come in, its parents close behind. I took the chick back outside and opened the windows for its parents, who fluttered overhead, making the monosyllabic monotonous note of the cardinal, tinged now with a palpable air of distress.

title: Measurex Corp.(MX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $ 524,000, or 3 cents a share, from the adoption of FAS 109, accounting for income taxes.Measurex said that net income for the latest quarter was hurt by an increase in the overall tax rate that resulted in a 43 percent tax rate due to a change in the geographic mix of earnings.

title: Smucker (J.M.) Co. (SJM.A,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 4,454,000, or 15 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.J.M. Smucker attributed its lower earnings in the current year to introductory advertising expenses in April for the Mrs. Smith's SmartStyle line of thaw-and-serve desserts and to the write-off of goodwill of a foreign unit.The company attributed its increased sales to inclusion of results from Canada Group East, formerly the jam division of Culinar Inc., and the Mrs. Smith's division, since their acquisition.J.M. Smucker also has class B shares with the ticker symbol SJM.B.

title: 2d Opinion for Your Portfolio
description: A second opinion on an investment portfolio can accomplish as much as a second opinion on medical care, providing peace of mind and increasing the chance any flaws will be detected.

title: 5 Each Get 40 Years In Waco Case
description: Ignoring pleas for leniency from the defendants and the forewoman of the jury that convicted them, a Federal judge today sentenced five Branch Davidians to 40 years in prison for their roles in a shootout near Waco in February 1993 in which four Federal agents and six cult members died.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF King Two Rounds Away From Hall Betsy King moved a step closer to the L.P.G.A. Hall of Fame, shooting a four-under-par 68 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead in the second round of the International in Rochester, N.Y. Three birdies on the back nine put King at 10 under over all, one ahead of Michele Redman, whose career-best finish was a tie for eighth at the Atlanta Women's Championship in April. Dawn Coe-Jones of Canada and Lisa Kiggens were at 8 under. King would automatically enter the Hall of Fame if she wins her 30th tournament tomorrow at the par-72 Locust Hill Country Club. King has earned $4.6 million in her 17 years on tour. This year, she has struggled on the greens, and her best finish was a tie for third at the Lady Keystone Open last month. (AP)

title: New Yorkers Can Help Care for Their Trees
description: To the Editor:

title: Douglas Bryant, 80 Leader in the Growth Of Harvard Libraries
description: Douglas W. Bryant, the director of Harvard University's libraries from 1972 to 1979, a period of rapid expansion, died on Sunday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. Mr. Bryant, who lived in Lexington, Mass., was 80.

title: Bridge
description: A winning tournament debut is not uncommon in events restricted to players owning fewer than five master points, but it happened in more spectacular fashion at the Eastern Regional Championships in Manhattan last month. John Wei of Queens, Peter Shao of West Windsor, N.J., and Fonda Charne of Brooklyn won the Swiss Team event for players with fewer than 100 master points. They had not a single master point among them, but now have 2.92 each and have joined the American Contract Bridge League.

title: Keep Prevention in the Crime Bill
description: As the crime bill begins its journey through a Senate-House conference committee, some of its more enlightened provisions will come under attack as wasteful, as pandering to criminals, as attempts to revive discredited Great Society-style social programs.

title: Recognizing Gay Athletes
description: Besides providing the setting for the Stanley Cup, the World Cup and maybe a basketball trophy too, New York City gets to play host to Gay Games IV for the next eight days -- with more athletes than the Olympics but still struggling for acceptance.

title: Club Med Inc.(CMI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Thomas Rudel, 89, Executive, Is Dead
description: Thomas Ryder Rudel, a leader in the machine-tool industry, died last Friday at St. Francis Hospital in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He was 89 and lived in West Park, N.Y.

title: SUNDAY, June 19, 1994; Best Postures
description: Who better than a group of chiropractors knows good posture when they see it? That's why the American Chiropractic Association's list of "Notable Celebrity Postures" of 1994 has a veneer of validity that most other celebrity lists do not.

title: Ms. Arredondo And Mr. Rolfe
description: Fabiola Raquel Arredondo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carlos A. Arredondo of Greenwich, Conn., and Madrid, was married yesterday to Andrew John Rolfe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Terrence Rolfe of Johannesburg. Msgr. Charles W. Stubbs performed the ceremony at St. Marys Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: I HAVE to tell you about the walk I took the other day. Two walks, actually (maybe technically), but I prefer to think of them as one, which, as you will come to see, is very much the point of this column.

title: SUNDAY, June 19, 1994; Canadian Hat Dance
description: What to do about Canada's hat thing? When the Royal Canadian Mounted Police decided a few years ago to let Sikh officers wear turbans instead of Mountie hats, many hat-proud Canadians were in an uproar. Now, the Royal Canadian Legion, the country's main veterans' group, has voted down a provision to allow religious headgear in legion halls. Individual chapters may bar observant Sikhs and Jews, as a few do now, and many freedom-loving Canadians are in an uproar. The remedy -- name a Minister of Hats. John Cleese, former Monty Python Minister of Silly Walks, is the obvious choice. Perhaps he could get Canada to get serious.

title: A Brash Kid No More: The Maturing of a Maestro
description: IF YOU THINK MICHAEL Tilson Thomas is still that brash kid looking over Leonard Bernstein's shoulder, you probably have not kept up with his recordings. But it hasn't been easy to do so. Mr. Thomas's recorded output is scattered on six different labels, and many of his fine early recordings are out of print or have been reissued in confusing repackagings. Mr. Thomas has recorded with many orchestras -- though mainly with the London Symphony, of which he has been principal conductor since 1988, and the New World Symphony, his superb training orchestra in Miami Beach.

title: Corrections
description: The Architecture View column on page 34 of the Arts and Leisure section today, and a picture caption with it, about the concept of "queer space," misspell the name of a New York center for gay youth in some copies. It is the Hetrick-Martin Institute.

title: Opponents of Disney Park Find Allies in Congress
description: A festering dispute between advocates and foes of a theme park that the Walt Disney Company is planning to build near important Civil War battlegrounds has spilled out of Virginia and into Congress, turning what began as a local spat into a national debate.

title: Vacation-Home Sales
description: Following is a sampling of second homes that recently changed hands in areas popular with residents of the New York metropolitan area. THE BERKSHIRES LENOX $222,500 222 Old Stockbridge Road 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old, wood-frame Cape Cod, dining room, eat-in kitchen, fireplace, 2-car garage, 1 acre, 2 1/2 miles from Tanglewood; taxes $1,953, listed at $239,000, 3 weeks on market (Brokers: BGH Realty; Ruffer-Arms Real Estate)

title: Not Special Rights, Just Ordinary Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: 30 Years Later, It's Freedom Summer Again
description: THIS MONTH MARKS THE 30TH anniversary of the Freedom Summer, when 1,000 college students from the North traveled to Mississippi to register black voters. The unbridled optimism of the movement, the cynicism that managed to stifle it at that summer's Democratic National Convention and its legacy in the lives of its participants are represented in the documentary "Freedom on My Mind," which opens Wednesday at Film Forum.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 32 of the Arts and Leisure section today about an exhibition of paintings by Thomas Cole at the National Museum of American Art in Washington includes an outdated reference to the show's travel schedule. After the section went to press, the museum announced that the exhibition would open at the Brooklyn Museum on Jan. 13, 1995. It will also be on view, as scheduled, at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford beginning Sept. 11.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Jamesburg; A Down-Home, No-Frills Community
description: JAMESBURG is a community with no frills. The Middlesex County borough of less than a square mile has no industry, no high school, no supermarket, two traffic lights and very few houses valued at more than $200,000. Yet for its fiercely loyal residents it has the comfort of an old shoe.

title: WOULD YOU BAPTIZE AN EXTRATERRESTRIAL?
description: The work of the Jesuit astrophysicists so interestingly portrayed by Jack Hitt raises a question. Why assume that God's only Son is necessarily an only child? Maybe Jesus has a Sister? On one of those billions of planets, she could be an incarnation of the same God worshiped by so many on Earth.

title: Canada Rebuffs Veterans of U.S. Forces in Vietnam
description: During the Vietnam War, as thousands of young Americans sought refuge in Canada to avoid the conflict, thousands of young Canadians were recruited by the United States to fight in that same war.

title: Rachel S. Moore, Robert M. Ryan
description: Rachel Suzanne Moore, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles V. Moore of Davis, Calif., was married yesterday to Robert Michael Ryan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael R. Ryan of Grosse Pointe, Mich. The Rev. Janelle Curlin performed the Unitarian ceremony at the Beaulieu Gardens in Rutherford, Calif.

title: Trait of Kindness
description: To the Editor: What struck me most about Margo Kaufman's story of coping with her hip injury while on a tour of Southeast Asia ("On a Limp and a Prayer," April 17) were the numerous instances of concern and kindness shown her by total strangers. As an American traveling 9,000 miles from home, Ms. Kaufman has shown us a positive side of human nature rarely presented on television, radio or in newspapers. Kindness, I believe, is a trait that transcends international boundaries. BRIAN G. KEOGH Massapequa, L.I.

title: In Game of Surprises, Early Goal Is Biggest
description: Soccer is full of surprises. But with all the hooting and hollering over Ireland's 1-0 victory over Italy yesterday, one of the most surprising things was how many people were surprised by the result.

title: How Black? How White?
description: THE SWEETER THE JUICE By Shirlee Taylor Haizlip. Illustrated. 271 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.

title: Just for Kicks
description: FEVER PITCH By Nick Hornby. 247 pp. New York: Penguin Books. Paper, $9.95. THE SIMPLEST GAME The Intelligent Fan's Guide to the World of Soccer. By Paul Gardner. 323 pp. New York: Collier Books/Macmillan Publishing Company. Paper, $12. TWENTY-TWO FOREIGNERS IN FUNNY SHORTS The Intelligent Fan's Guide to Soccer and World Cup '94. By Pete Davies. 290 pp. New York: Random House. Paper, $10. SOCCER! The Game and the World Cup. Edited by Elio Trifari and Charles Miers. Illustrated. 170 pp. New York: Rizzoli. $24.95.

title: Christopher Street: Changes Sweep the Gay Mecca
description: IT was once known as Skinner Road, hewing to an ancient dirt path that Indians used to carry lobsters and oysters inland from a cove on the Hudson. By 1799, it had been renamed Christopher Street.

title: Being Anonymous And Going Truant; Troubled Schools Feed Boredom
description: Every school day at Louis D. Brandeis High School in Manhattan, Alfred Cruz punches his student identification card into the machine just inside the front entrance. He steps onto a metal scanner and if the red light blinks on, he has to empty his pockets. He shoves his book bag through the X-ray machine, then he raises his arms so a security officer can wave a portable metal detector over his body like a wand.

title: Allied Soldiers March to Say Farewell to Berlin
description: Soldiers from the United States, Britain and France marched through Berlin today in a military farewell to the city their armies entered as victors and then guarded for nearly half a century.

title: Alison Sughrue, James Feeley 3d
description: Alison Mary Sughrue, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. O. Stevens Sughrue Jr. of Winchester, Mass., was married yesterday to James Aloysious Feeley 3d, a son of Patricia L. Feeley of Winchester and Mr. Feeley Jr. of Needham, Mass. The Rev. Paul S. Sughrue, an uncle of the bride, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the chapel at Salve Regina University in Newport, R.I.

title: The Welfare Perplex
description: At his best, President Clinton redefines old polarities and offers solutions that break the deadlock between conservatives and liberals. So welfare reform seemed an ideal candidate for the Clinton touch. Liberals would get tough with long-term clients of Aid to Families with Dependent Children, requiring them to work for a living; conservatives would back the financing to make work pay.

title: Fear of Defeat Clouds Debate on Health Care Bill
description: As the struggle for overhauling health care enters a critical stage, one of the most powerful pressures on Congress is a possibility that was simply unthinkable here until the last few weeks: that there might not be a major health care bill this year.

title: Brock B. Houghton, Martha H. Davis
description: Martha Hocking Davis, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Allan Davis of Cambridge, Mass., was married there yesterday to Brock Biddle Houghton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Richard Houghton of Cambridge. The Rev. Eugene V. N. Goetchius performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: What Is There to Do After School?
description: WHEN their parents are working, pre-teen-agers may not be ready to go home after school to an empty house. What do they do instead, at 3 P.M.?

title: Truck Traffic at Waste Site Raises Concerns
description: For 11 years, the ramshackle warehouses and storage tanks of a former waste-oil reserve and processing company on Review Avenue in Long Island City have gone unused as the property, which is on the state's long list of hazardous-waste sites, awaited cleanup.

title: JUNE 12-18: Rally Around the Pope; Cardinals Assail Proposals On the Rights of Women And Curbs on Population
description: The Vatican does not specialize in coincidences. Thus, when 114 of the Roman Catholic Church's 139 cardinals rallied last week to defend Pope John Paul II's opposition to proposals to be considered at a United Nations conference on population this year, the event had all the hallmarks of orchestration. The cardinals, who had been called to Rome to discuss preparations for Christianity's next millennium, endorsed an appeal by John Cardinal O'Connor of New York for the Cairo conference -- regarded by the Clinton Administration, American feminists and population experts as a pivotal opportunity to enhance the status of women -- to avoid "cultural imperialism" that would lead to abortion on demand, sexual promiscuity and distortions of traditional family values. Coming only weeks after the Pope himself used stern language to repudiate any talk of women in the priesthood, the cardinals' action seemed to offer one more confirmation that the Vatican is crusading against what it sees as a pervasive feminist challenge. ALAN COWELL

title: Breaking Free From a Seedy Image, Pool Gains in Popularity
description: POOL is making a big comeback in New Jersey, part of a heavily laundered revival of the sport. Once shunned as dens of iniquity filled by the likes of Minnesota Fats and Fast Eddie, the old pool halls and their seedy images have been slowly giving way to upscale looks with, in some places, valet parking, Perrier and perhaps a little wine. But no hard liquor, gambling or profanity.

title: POP BRIEFS
description: Praxis: 'Sacrifist' Subharmonic SD-7002-2; CD and cassette.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/BMW's M3; Germans Take Hot Recipe And Pour On More Spice
description: THERE is, I discover, more than one sort of purple mood. There is the one that has turned Prozac into America's favorite vehicle for driving away funk. And then there is the one provoked by that metallic plum in the driveway. That mood manifests itself in a foolish grin.

title: More Treasures to Explore
description: The Museum of Natural History celebrates two new galleries, June 6.

title: Brazil Inflation
description: To the Editor: We returned in March from three weeks in Brazil. Travelers should be aware of the chaotic situation of the currency. The official rate of inflation exceeded 40 percent in February, and the exchange rate of the dollar more or less follows inflation, climbing 1 or 2 percent daily. As a result it becomes necessary to change money daily. Another consequence is that many stores, hotels and restaurants do not accept credit cards. And if they do, they charge a premium of over 40 percent. This makes it necessary to deal in large amounts of cash.

title: Ms. Hendrickson And Mr. Kohn
description: Susan Emery Hendrickson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Hendrickson of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Robert Sharpe Kohn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Immanuel Kohn of Princeton. The Rev. Cynthia A. Jarvis performed the ceremony at the Nassau Presbyterian Church.

title: Huffman Up, Up, Up To U.S. Mark in Vault
description: Scott Huffman, the pole-vaulter from Kansas with the unique cartwheel style, sailed over the crossbar on his first attempt at 19 feet 7 inches today to set an American record on the final day of the USA/Mobil outdoor championships.

title: Boscobel Expanding Shakespeare Event
description: THIS is the story of a beautiful but overlooked mansion, an ambitious Shakespearean troupe and the actor Kevin Kline. If the story has a perfect ending, all will come together.

title: Tax Assessments With Distortions
description: To the Editor:

title: In Search of Democracy for Roosevelt Island
description: Twenty-five years ago, planners designed a new community on Roosevelt Island with painstaking attention to detail, including special street lamps, an exotic aerial tramway and futuristic vacuum tubes for garbage removal. But one thing left out of the plan, contend many of the 8,000 people who now live there, was a democratic say in their own affairs.

title: Sports of The Times; Open-and-Shut Case of Torture
description: It is the only golf course that's a National Historic Landmark, but to the golfers in the United States Open it's more of a National Historic Land Mine.

title: When Silence Was Golden
description: SEDUCTIVE CINEMAThe Art of Silent Film.By James Card.Illustrated. 319 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

title: Alarm Program for Women in Danger
description: A PROGRAM that provides free alarm systems to victims of domestic violence who are found to be in danger of being killed by their abusers is operating in six counties in New Jersey and will be expanded to four others over the next several months.

title: Welfare as We've Known It
description: President Clinton stood in a Kansas City bank lobby last week and vowed to bring radical change to the nation's system of public assistance.

title:
SOAPBOX;
Wanted: a New Deal for Cabbies
description: IN his budget proposal, Mayor Giuliani says he wants to dismantle the Taxi and Limousine Commission. The day that happens I might just declare a national holiday. In the drivers' world, T.L.C. stands for tough luck for cabbies -- not tender loving care.

title:
The Executive Life;
Cruise Takes the Edge Off a Frantic Schedule
description: MARK McCORMACK has given a splendid new meaning to the phrase "corporate retreat."

title:
OUT OF ORDER;
The Right Vehicle for the Suburban Jungle
description: OUR new truck is a bit of an embarrassment. Neighbors call up and say: "See you bought a truck." (Pause.) "What're you going to do with it?"

title: How to Rest Easy: Turn Your Insurance Policy Into Bedtime Reading
description: Unless you speak insurance as a second language, your automobile policy may seem as incomprehensible as a repair manual for an intercontinental ballistic missile. But while that sheaf of papers may not make for exciting reading, it's a good idea to curl up with your policy once a year, just to review your coverage and consider changes that may be worthwhile.

title: Manager's Profile
description: Warren J. Isabelle Fund: Pioneer Capital Growth, $293 million in assets; 5.75% sales charge. Manager since 1990 inception. (Sponsor: Pioneer Funds, Boston.) Born: Jan. 17, 1952; Gardner, Mass.

title: A Son Grows a Little Older, a Father Grows a Little Younger
description: These are trash-talking, knee-whacking, buck-crazed times in the wide, worried world of sports. Cynicism comes easy. Disgust bites deep. Call it the Tin Age of Athletics.

title: POLL FINDS A LACK OF FAITH IN POLICE
description: New Yorkers express anxiety about the Police Department's ability to protect them, and many say there is widespread corruption in the force, according to a New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll.

title: 'The Waterworks'
description: "The fact that Henry Armstrong was buried did not seem to him to prove that he was dead: he had always been a hard man to convince." Thus begins "One Summer Night," one of Ambrose Bierce's most wicked short stories: two pages long, a coffin-side view of an exhumation. An exhumation also plays an important part in E. L. Doctorow's startling and spellbinding new novel, "The Waterworks." But what Mr. Doctorow has truly exhumed are the remains of the 19th-century genre of the science-detection mystery, originated by Poe and richly developed by Bierce and Wilkie Collins.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Dr. Douglas Rae; Cities in Decline, Solutions in Sight
description: DOUGLAS RAE, who lives in New Haven, worries about the fate of cities.

title: Police Buffeted as Tides in Simpson Case Change
description: Just days after the authorities had been criticized as too aggressive in handcuffing O. J. Simpson before questioning him in a double homicide, they were pilloried again today, this time by critics who said lax treatment stemming from his celebrity had enabled him to elude capture for more than six hours on Friday.

title: Mutual Funds; A Rise in Rates Lifts Money Funds
description: BOND prices have fallen markedly in 1994, but a silver lining is the increase in money market fund yields. Since Feb. 4, when the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the first time this year, the seven-day average yield on taxable money funds has risen to 3.59 percent, from 2.68 percent, the highest in two years.

title: Case Might Fit Pattern Of Abuse, Experts Say
description: While the killing of Nicole Brown Simpson has attracted unusual publicity, experts in domestic violence say that if her ex-husband, O. J. Simpson, is ultimately convicted, the case will fit an all-too-common pattern.

title: Property Managers Plan For Outside Monitoring
description: As property-management companies in the city rush to name monitors and tighten procedures after indictments in a scandal that prosecutors said defrauded co-ops and condominiums of millions of dollars, some people in the business are saying the industry needs external monitoring.

title: In Bethlehem, a Newly Opened Estate With Treasure Gardens
description: NEW YORK may have Kykuit, the wondrous Rockefeller estate, but Connecticut has its own brand of bucolic treasure: the Bellamy-Ferriday House and Gardens in Bethlehem, which was opened to the public on May 7. The estate, listed on the National Register of Historic Properties, representing a marriage of home, outbuildings and gardens, and the history of two significant families dating back to 1754.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column last Sunday about cruise ship accommodations for the disabled described Cruise Consultants International of Santa Monica, Calif., incompletely. In addition to being a travel agency, it consults with cruise companies on travel for the disabled.

title: Quietly, a Slice of Bronx History Disappears
description: A piece of 19th-century history vanished last week.

title: SURFACING
description: GALAS The party line: It has become something of a tradition at charity parties this season to end the event with a line dance. (Above, a benefit for the Fresh Air Fund). COOL Arnet sunglasses: The hip eye wear among surfers, snowboarders, rockers, etc. Reduces sunlight, attracts limelight. EXERCISE Power yoga: At fitness clubs all over, classic yoga poses are mixed with more rigorous exercise routines and moves like sit-ups and push-ups.

title: On Sunday; Beauty Glistens In Asphalt Heat Of a Half Court
description: IT is after work in the Chinatown park back of Foley Square and the day's more yearned-for event is under way. A man called Showtime is down, a black man glistening with sweat as he squats on the playground's green asphalt, panting and exhausted, on the edge of losing an impassioned basketball game in the day's accumulation of street heat.

title: Can Interstates 84 and 91 Be 'Smart' Highways?
description: ON the highway of the future, computer-directed cars will whisk motorists safely and swiftly to their destinations, avoiding traffic jams and accidents.

title: The Two Koreas: 5 Decades of Division
description: The division of the Korean peninsula, which may be breached slightly if the Presidents of North and South Korea meet for the first time, was invented by the Americans with Soviet help.

title: Stuck in Drydock, With 2,000 Miles to Go
description: This was not part of the plan. The 60-foot ocean racer, Hunter's Child, looked like the victim of its father's sword -- beheaded as it was -- sitting here in the water at the Little Harbor yacht basin without its mast.

title: WEDDINGS HEADLINE>Elizabeth Cohen And Neil Bercow
description: Elizabeth S. Cohen was married last evening in Old Westbury, L.I., to Dr. Neil R. Bercow. Rabbi Lee Friedlander officiated at the de Seversky Center.

title: Taking the Waters in Tuscany
description: THERE is a special attraction about complete idleness, especially when you are told it is good for your health. Watering places, in particular, seem to establish a tempo that becomes immediately congenial: an adagio that goes with emptying cups of more or less palatable liquid, window-shopping (Gucci, Cartier et al. have local outlets), newspaper-scanning (foreign papers at the kiosk halfway down Viale Verdi), and an occasional anodyne card game, never for money (loss would be bad for the heart as well as the temper), but for fun, to pass the seemingly endless, undemanding time.

title: Beached
description: It was cold and rainy as the Normandy invasion started, and nothing was going as planned.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in the Business Diary column last Sunday, tracking investment trends in South Africa, omitted the source of the data. It was the Investor Responsibility Research Center.

title: Fredric L. Gilde, Julie A. Alperin
description: Julie Ann Alperin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barry Alperin of New York, is to be married today to Fredric Lawrence Gilde, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jon Gilde of Dix Hills, L.I. Rabbi Harlan J. Wechsler is to perform the ceremony in the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Disbelieving Crowd Cheers the Juice
description: It was as though the Juice had once again broken into the secondary, slipped the safety and was running to daylight.

title: Kathleen Healey, H. J. Willcox Jr.
description: Kathleen Mary Francis Healey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Healey of Hempstead, L.I., was married yesterday to Herbert James Willcox Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. H. James Willcox of Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Charles A. Kraus performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Charles Borromeo Church in Brooklyn.

title: THE LAST WAR CRIMINAL
description: Thank you for Ted Morgan's article. Henri Bulawko's quote about his brother was not only the perfect ending to the piece but the definitive response to any query about the validity of Holocaust remembrance. ELLEN DIAMOND Highland Park, Ill.

title: More Than A Face
description: The supermodel lives on the top floor of an unremarkable midtown brownstone decorated with ivy outside and characterized by a dark and creaky stairway inside. There is no elevator and that, happily enough, eliminates the need for a Stairmaster.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: PERSEPHONE AND THE POMEGRANATE A Myth From Greece. Written and illustrated by Kris Waldherr. Unpaged. New York: Dial Books for Young Readers. $14.99. (Ages 4 to 8) PERSEPHONE Retold and illustrated by Warwick Hutton. Unpaged. New York: Margaret K. McElderry Books. $14.95. (Ages 7 and up)

title: Samara Bernot, Adam Meshel
description: Samara Alyce Bernot and Adam Reid Meshel, graduates of Columbia University and law students -- she at Fordham University, he at Columbia -- were married last evening. Cantor Richard Bottom officiated at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York.

title: 'Lost Decade' Drains Africa's Vitality
description: You don't have to be a detective to spot the decline in living standards in Africa. It hits you right away.

title: Cameron Paynter, Michael Nelson
description: Cameron Clark Paynter, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Grenville H. Paynter of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Robert Nelson, a son of Dr. Robert R. Nelson and Sue Nelson Messaglia, both of South Bend, Ind. The Rev. David Simpson performed the Congregational ceremony at the Stone Church in New Preston, Conn.

title: The Changing Face of Father's Day
description: FOR Donald Rosenberg and other men like him, Father's Day has taken on a different meaning in recent years. Newly divorced and with joint custody of two sons, he will spend today with his younger son's Cub Scout pack -- typical of a new breed of single fathers who are re-examining traditional notions of their roles. Mr. Rosenberg, a 45-year-old accountant from Yorktown, explained that he is "seeking a fresh definition of parenting."

title: BILL CLINTON'S ADHOCRACY
description: The Clinton adhocracy is not working because Bill Clinton isn't doing it well, not because there is anything inherently wrong with the idea ("Bill Clinton's Adhocracy," by Richard N. Haass, May 29). Adhocracies can be liberating and energizing -- but only in very skilled hands. Instead of "discouraging debate and dissent," a well-managed adhocracy (no, that is not an oxymoron) should encourage and respect both. The trouble starts when it's not clear who makes the final decision.

title: Boarded-Up, Alexander's Awaits New Life
description: Ever since Alexander's flagship store closed in bankruptcy two years ago, the dormant building has taken on a desolate look, its boarded-up facade serving as a magnet to graffiti writers and poster pasters.

title:
Viewpoints;
To Deal With Bad Boards, A New Shareholder Tool
description: FOR the last year or two, the biggest theme in corporate governance has been the duty of boards of directors to oversee management. But, despite the attention, few observers have addressed a central issue: How can shareholders, in a convenient, inexpensive and evenhanded way, deal with boards that seem to be failing?

title: Dancing (and Free Lessons)
description: STARTING Wednesday, New Yorkers will have a chance to dance under the stars at Lincoln Center's Fountain Plaza.

title: Beth Colt, P. K. Simonds
description: Elizabeth Saunders Colt, an actress in Los Angeles, and Peter Kemble Simonds, a screenwriter there, were married yesterday at her parents' house on Naushon Island, Mass. The Rev. Preston Hannibal, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title:
WORLD CUP '94;
Hagi Has Right Stuff in Romania's Upset
description: His temper is known to be as fiery as his play. In one of the final World Cup tuneup matches against Northern Ireland, Romanian midfielder Gheorghe Hagi spat in the face of an opponent and was ejected.

title: Designing a Framework for Diversity
description: NEXT WEEKEND, WHEN lesbians and gay men march through the streets of New York and other cities, they will be asserting something more than a political agenda. They will also be asserting the vitality of the public realm and the importance of the city street as one of its major manifestations: a symbol of the openness, tolerance and diversity of democratic society. By occupying that symbol in vast numbers, they hope to bring society closer to these ideals.

title:
THING;
A Seat Of Influence
description: WHAT: A reproduction of Charles and Ray Eames's molded plywood chair, known to collectors simply as LCW (lounge chair wood). Originally produced from 1946 to 1957 by Herman Miller Inc. of Zeeland, Mich., this was the first mass-produced chair to boast three-dimensional curves, an innovation that had a profound effect on 20th-century furniture design.

title: A Hostile Witness to History
description: A JOURNEY THROUGH ECONOMIC TIMEA Firsthand View.By John Kenneth Galbraith.255 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.95.

title: WOULD YOU BAPTIZE AN EXTRATERRESTRIAL?
description: I loved Jack Hitt's article "Would You Baptize an Extraterrestrial?" (May 29). I am pleased to see it acknowledged that science and religion can complement each other, in a progressive way. LAUREN KRAUT Roosevelt Island, N.Y.

title: No Big Change Needed, Just a Hands-Off Policy
description: One more victory, and the forecasters of pro basketball's impending collapse will have their champion. The unglamorous, unrepentant, unrevered and often unsightly Knicks will stand as survivors of the eight-month marathon, the best evidence yet that the apocalypse is upon David Stern, who might as well get with the program and outfit his players with skates and sticks.

title: How the Federal Reserve Sets Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-14 TWO KOREAS AGREE TO MEET The Presidents of North and South Korea agreed to meet for the first time since the peninsula was divided, under a proposal delivered by former President Jimmy Carter. 1 The division of the Korean peninsula was an American design. 12

title: If a Sao La Is Seen in the Forest, but Not by Scientists, Does It Exist?
description: MARCH 14In a stretch of dense and nearly impassable jungle on the border between northern Vietnam and Laos lurks one of the world's most elusive large animals. Never seen by outsiders, never photographed, the Pseudoryx nghetinhensis, or Vu Quang ox, was discovered only two years ago and remains known to science solely through bones, hides and a few uncertain traces in the forest.

title: Sally A. Morris and Alan A. Pardee
description: Sally Ann Morris, a daughter of Carol and Lester Morris of Bayside, Queens, was married yesterday to Alan Alexander Pardee, the son of Aida and Scott Pardee of New York. The Rev. Robert T. Ferrick performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Being Led Down A Garden Path
description: A dinner-dance at the New York Botanical Garden, June 9.

title: Relief From the Stress of Counting Beans, or Paper Clips
description: TO teach certified public accountants how to "lighten up" a group of them was asked to dress casually for a four-day training camp. Jeffrey Oster of Garden City showed up in a short-sleeve shirt under his jacket and tie. "This is casual," he said.

title: Jennifer Altman, Jason Lee Fein
description: Jennifer Sue Altman, a daughter of Linda and Earle Altman of Harrison, N.Y., was married last evening to Jason Lee Fein, a son of Monica and Fred Fein of New City, N.Y. Cantor Bernard Dienstag officiated at the Essex House in New York.

title: Helen C. Pearce, Todd L. Bequette
description: Helen Chapman Pearce, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Pearce of New York, was married yesterday to Todd Lewis Bequette, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Bequette of Gridley, Calif. The Rev. Stephen H. Phelps officiated at St. Peter's Presbyterian Church in Spencertown, N.Y.

title: Q. & A.
description: The Rules On Renting Co-op Units Q A year and a half ago I sublet the co-op I own in New York City after the board approved a one-year lease. The board limited the term of the lease to a year. At the time of the sublet the co-op's bylaws allowed a unit to be sublet for up to four years before the shareholder had to move back in or sell it. When the tenant rented my unit it was with the understanding that the four-year clause was in effect even though the lease was for only one year. The intent on both our parts was to sign a new lease for each of the four years. This year, part way into the second one-year lease, the co-op board changed the sublet period to a maximum of two years, after which I must either move back in or sell. Do I have the legal right to sublet my apartment in years three and four, either by grandfathering in the four-year sublet clause, which was in place at the time the lease was first signed, or by any other means? . . . Lynda Wels, New Canaan, Conn.

title: Man in the News; Rail Union's Hard Bargainer: Edward Yule Jr.
description: In a 40-year career with the Long Island Rail Road that has taken him from lowly ticket clerk to unchallenged leader of the largest union for the nation's busiest commuter rail line, Edward Yule Jr. has always known how to find the inside track.

title:
Hackensack Journal;
Police Department Extends Itself to Recruit More Minorities
description: AT the request of the Hackensack Police Department, 200 young people came to meet several department officials and officers here one recent evening. But none were in trouble with the law.

title: Study Says Anti-Drug Dollars Are Best Spent on Treatment
description: A dollar's worth of drug treatment is worth seven dollars spent on the most successful law-enforcement efforts to curb the use of cocaine, researchers say in a new study.

title: 'Flyin' West' on Stage
description: IF "hit," that crassly commercial tag, can be used in the nonprofit sphere of regional theater, pin it on "Flyin' West."

title: Corrections
description: The Interest Rates chart on the Money page last Sunday rendered the yield for the 30-year Treasury bond incorrectly. A corrected version appears today on page 00.

title:
In the Region/Long Island;
A Baldwin Development Promotes Racial Diversity
description: AFTER living for 16 1/2 years in a rental apartment in Mineola, James and Saundra Black have signed a contract on a three-bedroom town house in Woodland Estates, a Baldwin development. They expect to move by next month.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York House

title: Getting Down to Business on the Net
description: LARRY GRANT doesn't own a personal computer. He reluctantly bought his first facsimile machine early this year. Yet Mr. Grant, who manages Grant's Flowers and Greenhouses in Ann Arbor, Mich., is in the technology vanguard these days, with his own storefront in cyberspace.

title: Dr. Neukermans and Mr. Burlinson
description: Dr. Katrien Anja Neukermans, a daughter of Eliane Aernoudt Neukermans and Dr. Armand P. Neukermans of Palo Alto, Calif., was married yesterday to Robert Francis Xavier Burlinson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Burlinson of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. James Erps, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Stanford (Calif.) Memorial Church.

title: Watchdog Group Presses for a Better Metro-North Commute
description: CONNECTICUT residents making the daily trek to jobs in New York City may not realize it, but every month for the past nine years a watchdog group, commuters all, has gathered to make their ride smoother.

title: A Theater Hard to Define, but Always With a Bit of Adventure
description: MOST of the state's professional theaters play in the fall, winter and spring: the extent of a standard theater season. And then there are the summer playhouses. But what of the Foundation Theater, which is more than a summertime thing, but less than a year-round operation?

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
Dada Dearest
description: "One cannot understand Dada; one must experience it. Dada is immediate and obvious. If you're alive, you are a Dadaist." So declared the poet Richard Huelsenbeck in his introduction to THE DADA ALMANAC (Atlas/Serpent's Tail, paper, $19.99), a collection of manifestoes, poems, photographs and other documents collected on the occasion of the First International Dada Fair, held in Berlin in 1920. The almanac assembled contributions from leading exponents of Dada, an international cultural movement centered in Berlin with satellites in Zurich, Paris, Cologne, Barcelona and New York, among other cities. Contributors included Hugo Ball (who with his wife, the singer Emmy Hennings, launched Dada in Zurich in 1916 by opening the Cabaret Voltaire), the Romanian poet and Dada propagandist Tristan Tzara, the artists Francis Picabia and Hans Arp, and the architect, performance artist and agent provocateur Johannes Baader, among many others. Not represented in the almanac was the more politically active contingent of Berlin Dada, including George Grosz, John Heartfield and Wieland Herzfelde, an omission that points to the fractures in the ever-volatile movement that was born of the disgust of European artists and intellectuals with the carnage produced by the nationalist fever of World War I. This annotated edition of the almanac, the first to appear in English, includes an introduction in the form of a survey of the history of Dada by the editor and translator Malcolm Green, capsule biographies of Dada figures, and supplementary documents and photographs. This is a somewhat rough and ready edition with an agitprop quality, but it is nevertheless a crucial document for anyone interested in the history of the 20th-century avant-garde.MIGNON NIXON

title: Protecting an 8,400-Mile Legacy of Waterways
description: ASK Connecticut residents to name the state's rivers and most will mention the Connecticut, the Housatonic and the Farmington. Sometimes also the Thames and the Quinnipiac.

title: Knicks Take a Deep Breath at Hint of a Title in Air
description: A riveting Knicks season filled with memorable moments, intriguing twists and many challenges is one victory away from culminating in a championship.

title: Ms. Matsumoto, Mr. Iwakura
description: Rei Matsumoto, the daughter of Sanae Matsumoto and Dr. Seiji Matsumoto of Hyogo, Japan, is to be married today to Masakazu Iwakura, a son of Keiko and Yasunori Iwakura of Tokyo. The Rev. Richard Leonard is to officiate at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.

title: Portofino, For the Rich And Less So
description: SEVERAL years ago, a few of the Italians ensconced in villas on Portofino's green slopes, from which they could see their yachts down at the marina, were in the habit of sending their helicopters to Genoa, 15 miles to the northeast, every morning to fetch the newspapers from Milan and Turin in time for breakfast. The rotor noise irked other guests of Portofino, so in 1991 the municipal council, representing the little harbor town's 650 year-round residents, banned all choppers from its vast territory. And thus ended air service to one of the most elegant resorts along the Italian Riviera.

title: Elizabeth Matt, David Lemire
description: Elizabeth Kemper Matt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Matt 2d of New Hartford, N.Y., was married there yesterday to David Shaffer Lemire, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Lemire of Scottsdale, Ariz. The Rev. Paul Drobin performed the ceremony at St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church.

title: JUNE 12-18: More Uncertainty in Mexico; Rebels Reject Peace Plan, Leaving Elections in Doubt
description: In turning down a Government peace proposal they had tentatively accepted three months ago, rebels in Southern Mexico last week left not only peace in doubt, but also the outcome of the elections. Leaders of the rebel Zapatista National Liberation Army rejected the offer, saying the Government of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari had not done enough to insure democracy in Mexico. The Zapatistas said they would not resume fighting or interfere with the Aug. 21 elections, and they offered to resume negotiations, but only if they focus on national concerns. The rejected proposal had mostly addressed the poverty and inequity of Indians in the state of Chiapas.

title: Wilder Becomes the 4th to Enter Virginia's Fractious Senate Race
description: L. Douglas Wilder, whose wit and drive took him from segregation to the Virginia Governor's Mansion, today returned to his boyhood neighborhood here to declare his candidacy for the United States Senate.

title: Pierce Out of Wimbledon
description: The French Open finalist Mary Pierce, apparently still plagued by family strife, announced today that her long-awaited Wimbledon debut has been canceled. "For reasons far beyond my control, I've decided not to participate in the most prestigious and traditional tournament in the world," the 19-year-old Pierce explained in the statement she released after a meeting with officials of the All England Club this afternoon at Wimbledon, where play begins Monday.

title:
STYLE;
The 'I' of the Beholder
description: I saw her pants first, the perfect wide spring trousers: a scrolled, color-block print on a slate blue background, combining the best of Klimt and Klee. They were worn by a woman with a near-Kabuki face and the ripe-fruit torso of a Renoir. She looked astonishing, a crash course in the fine arts of dressing and maquillage.

title: It's a Fine Time for Taking Inventory
description: THIS is a great time to make a serious garden inventory. What is going to come up, or out, or has done so.

title: Not Guilty, Huh? Tell It to the Lie Detector
description: FOR HIS APPEARANCE ON Spain's most popular television show this winter, John Wayne Bobbitt dressed in his Sunday best and spoke softly, almost shyly, about his gentle and loving personality. "No, I never hit my wife," he assured the show's host. "No, I never forced Lorena to have sex with me," he told a panel of seven "experts" during an hour of questioning about the incident that made him famous.

title:
In the Region/New Jersey;
Getting Brokers Onto the Information Superhighway
description: THE state's residential real estate industry is about to get on the information superhighway, developing in the next six months a statewide data network designed to help consumers shop for homes and brokers close deals. The system will be developed by the New Jersey Association of Realtors and a technological partner.

title: Correction
description: An article on May 29 about the role of Washington, D.C., in American history misstated the circumstances that produced the famous World War II photograph of the American flag being raised on Iwo Jima.

title: Hack Writer Meets Earnest Painter
description: AMBITION & LOVEBy Ward Just.277 pp. Boston:A Richard Todd Book/Houghton Mifflin Company. $22.95.

title: Street Violence and Teen-Age Curfews
description: LATE-NIGHT violence involving teen-agers has become such a problem in Connecticut cities that a number of them have ordered youth curfews, imposing them just in time for the summer when the mayhem is worst.

title: Religious Issue Roils Colombia On Eve of Vote
description: In an echo of Colombia's 19th-century religious wars, the presidential election on Sunday may be swayed by charges that the Liberal Party candidate secretly promised to name a Protestant as his Education Minister.

title: THE LAST WAR CRIMINAL
description: I would like to suggest that Ted Morgan's article "The Hidden Henchman" (May 22) bring a respite from articles about the Holocaust. There are enough museums and sufficient evidence to insure that, no matter what lies are concocted by anti-Semites, the truth will prevail. As a Jew (who owns photos of slaughtered family members), I know that we must never forget. We can remember while we focus on current horrors. IRIS KAUFMAN Pittsburgh

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about a Supreme Court ruling in a death penalty case misidentified one of the Justices. He is David H. Souter, not Robert.

title:
Viewpoints;
Endangered: Tiny Bottles Of Hotel Soap
description: THE march toward environmental correctness is on, and it may work us business travelers into a lather.

title: Q and A
description: To Beijing From Hong Kong

title: Elizabeth Cluett, Reginald Thors
description: Elizabeth Tucker Cluett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Sturtevant Cluett of San Francisco, was married yesterday to Reginald Fincke Thors, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thor Thors Jr. of New York. The Rev. Charles H. Clarke Jr. performed the Episcopal ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Blue Hill, Me.

title: Tradition! The Senior Prom '94
description: ROW upon row of neatly boxed corsages line the refrigerator shelves at the Rodier Flower Shop in Ridgefield. Tuxedos ordered weeks before have been picked up, cars have been washed and waxed and cocktail dresses hang waiting in closets around town.

title: Our Vietnam Blunder
description: To the Editor:

title: Tech Notes; Product Prognostication, and Then the Unveiling
description: THEY do things differently in the computer industry, and new-product announcements are a good example.

title:
Viewpoints;
Marketers, Stop Your Tinkering
description: BUSINESS is simple. Revenues minus costs equal profits.

title: Julie Hock, James McLaughlin
description: Julie Hock, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Hock of Orange, Conn., was married yesterday to James H. McLaughlin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard McLaughlin of Woodbury, Conn. The Rev. George LaLiberte performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Teresa's Church in Woodbury.

title: SUNDAY, June 19, 1994; Death and Taxes
description: Americans are supposed to hate unpleasant truths. Walter Mondale committed an unforgivable sin when he was running for President in 1984 and said he would have to raise taxes. Ronald Reagan, who practiced public denial, won.

title: Business Diary: June 12-17
description: COMPANIES At Simon & Schuster, a Pawn in the Corporate Game Publishing sometimes seems a world apart, exempt from big-money corporate chess games. But the outside world crashed in on this literary island last week when Viacom, which recently acquired Simon & Schuster as part of its Paramount package, swooped into the publishing house and sacked the man who'd built it into a powerhouse in recent decades, Richard E. Snyder. The publishing world's reaction: shock, mystification -- and jitters about the fate of various authors. Viacom gave a well-worn explanation: a difference in styles. But it soon spied a gathering storm, and moved quickly to calm it, going out of its way to state its "commitment to literature and the printed word." Of course, not everyone at Simon & Schuster mourned, as some were glad to bid farewell to what they called Mr. Snyder's explosive temper. They expected his successor, Jonathan Newcomb, to set a softer tone.

title: Rachel M. Cohen, Allan M. Goldstein
description: Rachel Margolit Cohen, a daughter of Drs. Donald and Phyllis Cohen of Woodbridge, Conn., is to be married today to Dr. Allan Moises Goldstein, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jacob Goldstein of Wyncote, Pa. Rabbi David Avigdor is to perform the ceremony at Congregation B'nai Jacob in Woodbridge.

title:
DANCE;
His Dance Technique Is Rooted in Chain Reaction
description: TO THE AVERAGE PERSON, THE term contact improvisation means little. But to a whole generation of choreographers and dancers, contact improvisation is akin to the gospel, a training technique that has had enormous influence on their approach to movement and dance making.

title:
FRUGAL TRAVELER;
A Slice of Neighborhood Life On the Left Bank in Paris
description: THE ninth-floor terrace cafe at the Samaritaine Department Store No. 2, just north of the Pont Neuf, serves coffee, tea, miniature pizzas and something far more remarkable (not to mention free) -- a sweeping panorama of the Left Bank of Paris from the Eiffel Tower to the Jardin des Plantes. I stood there one sunny afternoon in late April, counting the nine Seine bridges within view, just as 3 o'clock struck and the city's church bells joined in a mad cacophony right out of "The Hunchback of Notre Dame."

title: Yeltsin's Anti-Crime Decree Sets Off a Storm of Outrage
description: When President Boris N. Yeltsin announced last week that he was preparing an urgent decree that would finally reckon with Russia's powerful mobsters -- "criminal filth" he called them -- the nation was delighted.

title: Treasury Says a Worker Took $1.7 Million in New $100 Bills
description: A 31-year-old Maryland man who worked in the main plant of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing has been charged with stealing $1.7 million in new $100 bills, Government officials said today.

title: Streetscapes/The American Museum of Natural History; A Vaux Masterpiece Eroded and, Now, Ignored
description: "THE name Calvert Vaux is about to emerge from the shadows of American history," begins William Alex's exhaustive monograph "Calvert Vaux Architect & Planner," published this month by Ink Inc. ($100).

title:
The View From: Fairfield;
A Living Lab for the Children Called the Mill River
description: THE five trails that run along the Mill River at Perry's Pond are blooming with growth and bustling with students. As one group measures the rate of the rushing river, another collects samples of microorganisms in the still marsh. It's all part of an award-winning science-based program within the Fairfield school system known as the Mill River Wetland Committee's River-Lab. It's purpose is to heighten awareness of the environment and find ways to insure its future health.

title:
WORLD CUP '94;
Road to the World Cup Was Rocky for a Swede
description: Whatever obstacles Klas Ingesson had to overcome to make Sweden's national team and then the World Cup, nothing stood in his way like the moose that emerged in the path of his car on a country road in his homeland last month.

title:
Profile;
Executive, Interrupted: Wall St. Star Bounces Back
description: HE didn't know what hit him. Suddenly and uncontrollably, Robert H. Lessin spun like a top and collapsed in a heap on the tennis court of his New Jersey estate.

title: Tougher Laws On Domestic Violence Facing Vote
description: WHEN Colleen McHugh broke off a romantic relationship in 1989, it was the beginning of a five-year nightmare that ended on Jan. 20 when her former boyfriend shot her to death at her sister's home and then killed himself.

title: Capturing the Pounding Pulse of New York City
description: EVEN IF YOU LISTEN HARD TO the music that begins "N.Y.P.D. Blue," you won't hear the sound of 1,000 Japanese men jumping up and down on a wooden floor, but Mike Post says they're there. Not only floor stampers but also a cheese grater slowed down, anvils, an aluminum wall and a subway horn. Mr. Post's goal was to create a tom-tom sound even bigger than the one in Phil Collins's "In the Air Tonight," which for Mr. Post is the tom-tom sound. It took a team of recording engineers two days to get it right.

title: Some Come Out
description: ANONYMITY By Susan Bergman. 198 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. THE FAMILY HEART A Memoir of When Our Son Came Out. By Robb Forman Dew. 229 pp. New York: Addison-Wesley Publishing Company.

title: Gay Games Are Opened In Pageantry
description: The Gay Games began officially yesterday as thousands of athletes and spectators gathered in Manhattan for a gala opening ceremony that included marching bands, several standing ovations, and a baton twirler in a two-foot-tall beehive hairdo.

title: Lauren Rosenthal, Salvador C. Uy
description: Lauren Abby Rosenthal, the daughter of Dan and Pamela Rosenthal of East Hampton, L.I., was married there yesterday to Salvador Castro Uy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Uy of Jamaica Estates, Queens. Justice Katherine Cahill of the East Hampton Town and Village Court, officiated at the civil ceremony in the home of the bride's parents.

title: Moonachie Pupils Flirt With Prayer Ban
description: THE local school in this Bergen County town will be testing the United States Supreme Court's ruling against prayer in state-sponsored schools when 28 eighth graders graduate tomorrow night.

title:
Your Own Account;
Underregulated to Under Scrutiny
description: THE Internal Revenue Service is often secretive, particularly in audit investigations. But the agency is telling the news media and tax lawyers about its continuing examination of 403(b) plans, the tax-deferred retirement plans used by employees of nonprofit groups.

title: Which City Has the Sharp Elbows?
description: After 54 long years without a Stanley Cup, New York City hockey fans made up for lost cheering last week when the Rangers beat the Vancouver Canucks in Game 7 of the finals at Madison Square Garden.

title: Louise Sinnott, Michael Stocker
description: Louise Marie Sinnott, a special-projects manager at Parker Media, a publishing company in Hartford, and Dr. Michael Aubrey Stocker, the president of the Cigna Healthplans insurance company there, were married yesterday. The Rev. Orlanda Brugnola, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Boathouse Cafe in New York.

title: New Twist on Barbecued Chicken Dinner
description: GRILLED chicken, potato salad and pie: these are the quintessential dishes of outdoor summer barbecues. The following menu, however, gives these old favorites a new twist.

title: From Apartment Window, A Drama of Man vs. Bee
description: To The Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MEMOIR WARRIORS DON'T CRY A Searing Memoir of the Battle to Integrate Little Rock's Central High. By Melba Patillo Beals. Pocket Books, $22.

title: Flora and Fauna With Fantasy Touches
description: THE flora and fauna at the Walker-Kornbluth Gallery are a delightful introduction to the idylls of summer gardens. Paintings and photographs of lush blossoms line the walls with vibrant colors, while the craft selection includes peaceable animals in nearly every nook. Several have plants sprouting from their backs.

title: Repairs Making Coachman More Livable
description: LONG regarded with opprobrium by housing and human rights advocates and with fear and dismay by its neighbors, the Coachman Hotel in downtown White Plains has served as little more than a warehouse for homeless families.

title: 'California Style' Innovations on Pizza
description: ON Long Island, California Pizza Kitchen falls into the "never heard of it" category. Its wood-fried Thai chicken, Southwestern burrito, goat cheese, Peking duck and moo-shu chicken California pizzas are virtually unknown here, even by adventurous pizza lovers.

title: Tally Chamberlin, C. H. Harris
description: Lisa Talbot Chamberlin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Larry Lee Chamberlin of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., was married there yesterday to Christopher Hardy Harris, the son of Dianne Trautmann of Fairfax, Va., and William Gibson Harris 2d of Riverside, Conn. The Episcopal ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Hale at St. John's Church.

title: Arafat's Return Is a Call to Arms for Many Israelis
description: Yasir Arafat has Ankie Rekhess-Spitzer in emotional turmoil.

title: Organizing a City: A Celebration From A to Z
description: LAST month, Mayor Giuliani asked his Labor Commissioner to have a quiet talk with George M. Steinbrenner, the Yankees' owner, about what was good for the city.

title: At Turning Point, a Warm Give-and-Take
description: JUST across the Tappan Zee Bridge from Westchester, off the first exit in Rockland County, down a steep San Francisco Lombard Street-like hill, on the main drag of this one-stoplight town is the Turning Point. Built in 1835, the former boarding house is the only club near Manhattan besides the Towne Crier in Pawling that caters to folk, blues and American roots music.

title: 'WE'RE ALL RACIST NOW'
description: It is no wonder that Bill Paterson's pupils are unruly and academic failures. He has such obvious disdain for them.

title: Road Projects Galore, and Not a Place to Turn
description: SUSAN STARR used to take 20 minutes to commute to work from Syosset to Lake Success, until construction started on the Long Island Expressway . . . and the Northern State Parkway . . . and Jericho Turnpike and . . .

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS McGrath Wins an All-American Battle In Eastbourne, England, Meredith McGrath won the battle of unseeded Americans yesterday to take a grass-court championship with a 6-2, 6-4 victory over Linda Harvey-Wild. The triumph gave McGrath her second career title and solidified her comeback after injuries kept her off the tour for 18 months.(AP)

title:
ART;
Rugged Paintings Showing the Evanescence of Photography
description: MADELEINE HATZ makes Marco Polos out of her audience with an exhibition of recent painting at the Trans Hudson Gallery. She paints abstract landscapes that can resemble tapestries. But the viewer does more than gaze at them; he is bidden to explore them.

title: SUNDAY, June 19, 1994; New From Disney: Your Wedding, The Animated Feature
description: Reinventing tradition to blend into a theme park landscape is the Disney stock in trade. Consider Main Street U.S.A., Fort Wilderness and the "Victorian elegance" of the Grand Floridian Beach Resort. Now young lovers can add weddings -- modeled on the Disney version of fairy tales.

title: Dr. McKibbin, Dr. Lloyd-Jones
description: Dr. Kathleen Margaret McKibbin, an internist, is to be married today to Dr. Donald Miller Lloyd-Jones, a third-year resident in internal medicine, both at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. The Rev. Thomas McDonald is to perform the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of the Good Shepherd in Rhinebeck, N.Y.

title: It's No Two-Bit Luxury
description: To step into the Broadway Barbershop is to step into a dimly remembered past. From the striped pole to the steel and leather articulated barber chairs (equipped with headrests and strops) to the tile-and-mirror decor, it is the picture of an old-time barbershop. With his white smock and courtly manner, Kay Demitriou, known to his patrons as Mr. Kay, is an old-fashioned barber. Rarer still, he is a barber who still gives an old-fashioned barber shave.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HISTORY RESISTANCE The Warsaw Ghetto Uprising. By Israel Gutman. Marc Jaffe/Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.

title: 'WE'RE ALL RACIST NOW'
description: I teach college students, some of whom are inmates at a medium-security prison. I suspect my students had teachers like Bill Paterson in high school.

title: Hundley and the Mets Get The Message on Hitting
description: This time, Dallas Green did not scream. He did not kick garbage cans and he did not use incredible amounts of profanity when he addressed his slumping Mets.

title: Wall Street; Stockpile Concerns Create Problems for a Stock
description: CHEYENNE Software Inc. lost more than half its value on Friday, after the computer software company said earnings in the quarter that ends June 30 would be disappointing. Cheyenne lost $8.375, to close at $8.

title: The Truth of the Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: Innovative Sondheim, Past and Present
description: THE WHOOPERS WERE OUT AT the final preview of "Merrily We Roll Along," the York Theater Company's smart-looking revival of the 1981 Stephen Sondheim-George Furth musical, which is now at St. Peter's Church. You may not know what whoopers are, but you've heard them. They're those members of the audience who seem to try to orchestrate curtain calls, most often at previews, revealing themselves with short, shrill yips that sound like rebel yells, sometimes like broncobusters in heat. They couldn't quite whoop up a standing ovation for "Merrily We Roll Along," but they came close.

title: New United: Friendly Skies or Bloody Sunday?
description: WOULD you like to own shares in a company run by its unions? What about bonds?

title: Jamie Wortman, Joel B. Manning
description: Jamie Hope Wortman, a daughter of Toni and Walter Wortman of East Northport, L.I., was married last evening to Joel Bruce Manning, a son of Myra and David Manning of Woodbury, L.I. Rabbi Ezra Finkelstein officiated at the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel.

title: Ruffles and Flourishes
description: Four celebrations and benefits around New York.

title: A Profile Misses the Important Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: After 16 Years, Minor League Baseball Returns
description: IT was the fall of 1927, and Sam Plumeri was living a 13-year-old's fantasy come true. A batboy, he was standing at the dugout, watching Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig walking onto Wetzel Field in Trenton, waving at the crowd.

title:
WHAT'S DOING IN;
Montreal
description: Montrealers are celebrating their brief summer outdoors after one of the longest, coldest and snowiest winters of any major city.
