description: Defensive lineman JERRY BALL, a three-time Pro Bowler, signed with the Los Angeles Raiders yesterday. Ball, 29, played six seasons with the Detroit Lions before being traded to the Cleveland Browns last season. Terms of the deal were not announced. (AP)

title: Pro Bono Accounts
description: * Broadway Theater Institute, New York, to Borejko Leibler, New York. * Make-a-Wish Foundation of Metro New York, Port Washington, L.I., to F& D Advertising, Westbury, L.I. * Y.W.C.A. of the City of New York, to DDB Needham New York.

title: Fratricide in Bosnia: Muslim vs. Muslim
description: This Bosnian village set in undulating countryside has become the most active front line in Bosnia over the last week, and the heart of a bizarre and intensifying conflict that has set Muslim against Muslim in a fratricidal war.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-10 FRENCH TROOPS OUTSIDE RWANDA France moved troops to the Rwandan border in preparation for a mission to try to end ethnic killing, but France said it would not send the troops in unless both the Government and the rebels agreed. A2 ANOTHER WAR IN BOSNIA The northern Bihac area of Bosnia has become the most active battle front, and unlike the rest of the country, the fighting is between the mostly Muslim Bosnian Government and a breakaway Muslim group. A3

title: Personal Health; Making sure that children play it safe with the sun.
description: SCHOOL is almost out and millions of youngsters will be outside playing from dawn to dusk. But while they frolic in the summer sun, many will be overexposed to the sun's skin-damaging ultraviolet rays.

title: Out-of-Court Settlement Reached Over Love Canal
description: Closing a major chapter in one of the nation's most notorious environmental disasters, the company that buried chemical wastes at Love Canal reached an out-of-court settlement with New York State yesterday, agreeing to pay $98 million and to take on cleanup work that will extend for decades, at a cost of millions more.

title: Dollar's Slide Against Yen Marked by Orderly Trading
description: The dollar fell to a new post-World War II low against the Japanese yen yesterday, continuing a slide that has lopped off 5 percent of its value in a little more than two weeks. The dollar briefly traded below 100 yen for the first time.

title: People
description: * Paul Turcotte was named advertising director of Field & Stream and Outdoor Life magazines, New York, succeeding Jonathan Stone, who became associate publisher of Bicycling magazine. Mr. Turcotte was previously advertising director of Playboy magazine, New York.

title: Winter Sports, Summer Soldiers, City on the Edge; As 7th Game Follows 7th Game, New York Fans Find Their Nerves Stretched Taut
description: Go Ricks! Go Knangers!

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CELLULAR GROUP INC., Sarasota, Fla., has completed an agreement to acquire Voice Data Communications Inc., from Communications Associates Ltd. The terms were not disclosed. HARRIS CORP., Melbourne, Fla., said it had won an Air Force contract, worth as much as $51 million in the next 10 years, to make portable terminal systems that would allow ground troops to obtain weather information.

title: Veteran Bronx Educator Appointed to Central School Board
description: Sandra Lerner, a professional educator with close ties to the teachers' union, was appointed yesterday to New York City's central Board of Education by Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer.

title: Philip Morris Goes on the Offensive
description: Philip Morris is out to convince Wall Street that cigarette smoking can be good for its financial health.

title: Market Place; Incorrect Prices Turn Fidelity's Face Red
description: Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest mutual fund company, deliberately provided incorrect information on the value of its mutual funds last week, causing newspapers to report that most Fidelity funds did substantially better than they actually did.

title: Jets Sign Anthony Johnson and Two Picks
description: The Jets yesterday signed running back ANTHONY JOHNSON, an unrestricted free agent from Indianapolis, and came to terms with two of their draft picks, receiver RYAN YARBOROUGH, who was taken in the second round, and quarterback GLENN FOLEY, taken in the seventh. None of the terms were disclosed. The Jets' general manager, DICK STEINBERG, said none of the signings would cause the team to make room under their salary cap by releasing other players.

title: Lotus Development
description: Lotus Development continued its plunge yesterday, following its announcement after the market closed on Monday that results for its current quarter would not meet estimates. The stock plummeted 28 percent from its Monday close, including after-hours trading on Monday.

title: Honors
description: * Reginald K. Brack Jr., president and chief executive of Time Inc., has been named the 1994-95 chairman of the Advertising Council, New York. He succeeds Philip H. Geier Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Interpublic Group of Companies. * Val Appel, a co-founder and past president of AHF Marketing Research, and Arthur Nielsen Jr., the former chairman of A. C. Nielsen Co., have been elected to the Market Research Council Hall of Fame.

title: Camp Memories
description: To The Home Section:

title: Allou Health & Beauty Care Inc.(ALU,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: U.S. Wins in Soccer
description: The U.S. shocked Colombia, 2-1, for its first World Cup victory since 1950.

title: As the car industry goes, so go the buff books. And right now, they're cruising in the fast lane.
description: THE benefits of the recovery in the American auto industry are being shared with the automotive enthusiast magazines, a publishing category that is rising to new levels of prosperity because of stronger advertising by the makers of cars and trucks.

title: Campus Drinking Problem Becomes Severe
description: To the Editor:

title: Budget Showdown at City Hall
description: New York City Council members' brave talk about defending programs for the poor seemed to end in the hours before dawn Tuesday when Speaker Peter Vallone sipped champagne with Mayor Rudolph Giuliani over a budget deal that gave the Mayor almost everything he sought.

title: Watts in Benefit Recital
description: The pianist Andre Watts is to give a recital on July 3 at 4 P.M. at the Tannery in Mount Lebanon Shaker Village in New Lebanon, N.Y. The program is to include two rondos by Mozart, a sonata and two scherzos by Schubert, Janacek's Sonata ("Oct. 1, 1905"), Berio's "Wasserklavier," and "Les Jeux d'Eau a la Villa d'Este" and two "Paganini" Etudes of Liszt. The recital is to benefit Classical Action, a management group that donates concert proceeds to AIDS organizations. Tickets are $100, including a champagne reception after the concert. Information: (518) 794-7887.

title: Where Confidentiality Is and Isn't Protected
description: To the Editor:

title: Houston Fans Show Their True Colors
description: There were fireworks, literally. Little blazing rockets boomed and shot across the ceiling of the Summit. Streamers dropped down from above, cloaking the players, the fans, even the police who forged a stern ring around the court, in red and gold.

title: Critics Assail Budget as Coucil Debate Wins
description: The $31.6-billion budget agreement between the Giuliani administration and leaders of the City Council was attacked yesterday by critics who questioned its fiscal assumptions and its spending cuts. But supporters rallied behind the agreement, which restored some projects with strong local support that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had planned to cut.

title: Journal; Addicted to O. J.
description: As one American man who doesn't consider professional football a national pastime, I never regarded O. J. Simpson as a hero or icon but merely as a bit player in disposable movies and a shill for the car-rental company that never seemed to offer the best rates. But this didn't stop me, or the other football ignoramuses with whom I was eating dinner Friday night, from scrambling to a television the moment the waitress told us that O. J. was fleeing on a freeway live on every network.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Thursday showing the National Weather Service's scale of "apparent temperatures" and a corrective version of the chart on Friday misstated two figures. When the temperature is 100 degrees and the relative humidity is 5 percent, the apparent temperature is 93 degrees, not 83. When the temperature is 75 and the humidity is 80, the apparent temperature is 78, not 73.

title: Youth Is Convicted in Murder for a Bicycle
description: A Brooklyn teen-ager was convicted of murder yesterday in the killing ofAllyn Winslow, 42, a drama teacher who was shot in the back last June as a groupof teen-agers tried to steal his bicycle in Prospect Park.

title: No Headline
description: "Before Stonewall, we had no rights. Police treated us like dogs. I remember thinking, when it was over, that I never had to be afraid again." -- DARIO MODON. [ A1:3. ]

title:
CURRENTS;
Easing the Job of Getting to Work
description: UNTIL recently, the way to the departure and arrival point for some 110,000 daily commuters using the Long Island Rail Road station at Pennsylvania Station was indirect and confusing. To get to their subterranean ticket windows and train platforms, riders filed through the various entrances among Penn Plaza's office slabs and the doughnut-shaped Madison Square Garden.

title: Edwards (A.G.) Inc.(N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Vietnam Finds First Live Example of Rare Ox
description: Two years of searching in Vietnam have led to the capture of a Vu Quang ox, a species that had been known only from skulls and pelts, the World Wildlife Federation announced yesterday. The federation said a calf caught by local hunters was grazing safely in a Vietnamese preserve.

title: Athletes With AIDS Virus Conquering the Challenges
description: "The disease is the gold medalist, the world champion that will beat all comers," Thomas C. Gehring said acidly, just before his blue eyes went as soft and unfocused as the chlorinated water of the swimming pools he loves to dive into. "The idea is to stay in the race as long as you can."

title: Drug Cartel Tied to Vote In Colombia
description: Hoping to buy leniency from the future Colombian President, a Cali cocaine cartel leader agreed to donate $3.75 million to the presidential campaign of Ernesto Samper Pizano, according to wiretap tape recordings made public here today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10 FRENCH TROOPS TO AID RWANDA France said it would move troops into Rwanda today to protect civilians against further killings there. Some 2,500 marines and Foreign Legion soldiers using helicopter gunships and vehicles will be involved in the operation, which will be launched from neighboring Zaire. A1

title: Bridge
description: When an opening bid of one spade receives a one no-trump response, locating the best game when the opener is very strong may be tricky. An old idea is to treat a jump to three clubs as an artificial forcing move, and this has been revived by Richard Schwartz of East Elmhurst, Queens. His team won the Reisinger Knockout Teams in early June, and earlier in the event, on the diagramed deal, he chose exactly the right moment to forget his own convention.

title: Anti-Gay Decree Splits Officials Family
description: Almost a year after commissioners in suburban Cobb County gained national attention by passing a resolution condemning homosexuality, a daughter of the commission's chairman announced today that she was a lesbian and called for the county to rescind the resolution.

title: F.C.C. Plan For License Diversity
description: The Federal Communications Commission is close to completing a plan that would give small businesses, women and members of minority groups preferences worth hundreds of millions of dollars in bidding on new licenses for wireless telephone and data communications.

title: Israelis, by and Large, Back Peace Process
description: To the Editor:

title: Kasatonov Is Signed by Bruins
description: The Boston Bruins have signed free-agent defenseman and former Soviet hockey star ALEKSEI KASATONOV, the team announced yesterday. Kasatonov, 34, played for 12 years on the Central Red Army team. He represented the former Soviet Union in eight world championships and played on Olympic teams that won gold medals in 1984 and 1988 and a silver medal in 1980.

title: Oneok Inc.(OKE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
The Unknown Designer (For Now)
description: THE best architecture and design that America has to offer: That was the mandate of officials at the American Center in Paris, a cultural institution in need of a modern building. For its new headquarters, which opened last month on the banks of the Seine, the center's board turned to Frank Gehry, the bemedaled guru of American deconstruction. But most of the interiors and all the furnishings went to a furniture designer who has been called a national treasure: John Hutton.

title: German Bankers Defend Lending Practices
description: German banks have been battered by three major financial scandals this year, but some of Germany's leading bankers still defend their lending practices as sound and maintain there is no need to adopt new safeguards or review their lists of corporate customers.

title: AAR Corp.(AIR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included an after-tax restructuring charge of $ 7.2 million, or 45 cents a share.Latest periods' results are preliminary.

title: Flyers Set Sights on Murray
description: TERRY MURRAY, former coach of the Washington Capitals, will be named coach of the Philadelphia Flyers, a television station reported yesterday. The Flyers have called a news conference for today to announce the hiring of a coach, and WPVI-TV in Philadelphia said it would be Murray, a friend and former teammate of BOBBY CLARKE, the Flyers' new president.

title: Prosecutor in Katie Beers Case Details Other Episodes of Abuse
description: Katie Beers has known more than her share of suffering in her short life. She was kidnapped and held in an underground bunker for 16 days, and she was sexually abused, prosecutors say, by her godmother's husband, Sal Inghilleri.

title: Executive Changes
description: BANTA CORP., Menasha, Wis., named Donald D. Belcher president and chief operating officer. DIAGNOSTEK INC., Albuquerque, N.M., appointed Andrew Masetti executive vice president and chief financial officer, assuming the responsibilities previously held by William Barron, who was recently named chief operating officer.

title: Sudan Detains Ex-Premier
description: Sudanese security forces have detained former Prime Minister Sadeq al-Mahdi and three of his aides on charges of plotting against the military Government, the state television reported this week.

title: Hard on the Trail Of Forgotten Roses
description: WE were rustling roses in western New Jersey, headed for the Pennsylvania line. The women in the deli in Clinton had told us to check out the town cemetery, but when we saw the men spraying around the graves with weedkiller, we made a U-turn.

title: Panel's Moderates Say a Compromise Is Near on Health
description: Moderate Democrats and Republicans on the Senate Finance Committee approached agreement today on a national health insurance plan that would require people to buy health insurance for themselves and not make employers buy it.

title: Maradona Lets Feet Talk for Him
description: The twists and turns are not as lightning-quick as they were in 1986, when he almost single-handedly led Argentina to its second World Cup triumph. He is still a little pudgy despite losing 26 pounds and upgrading his physical condition. And throughout the world, the soccer player once most widely written about has been written off.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Shaken Dollar

title: Anticipating Influx of Refugees, Miami Plans Schools for Aliens
description: Concerned that political troubles in the Caribbean might cause a major influx of refugees, Miami's school board today approved a contingency plan that would put the children of aliens into makeshift special schools rather than integrate them immediately into the district's already overcrowded schools.

title: Stocks Recover a Bit, Following the Dollar
description: After three punishing sessions in which the Dow Jones industrial average lost more than 100 points and nearly 3 percent of its value, the stock market recovered modestly yesterday as it awaited developments in the wandering course of the dollar and of commodities prices, especially for oil.

title: Gtech Holdings Corp.(GTK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
Economic Scene; Back to the days of expensive oil? Don't top off your tank yet.
description: OIL for $20 a barrel? Is OPEC on the march again?

title: Campus Drinking Problem Becomes Severe; Beneficial in Moderation
description: To the Editor:

title: Russia Hides Effort to Develop Deadly Poison Gas, U.S. Says
description: Russia is concealing efforts to develop advanced chemical weapons, despite its pledge to disclose details of its poison gas program to the United States, Clinton Administration officials said today.

title:
CURRENTS;
Convenience in New Forms
description: TAKE note, environmentally conscious summer house guests: that bastion of modernism, the MOMA design store at 44 West 53d Street, is going back to nature.

title: Peggy Pollack; Magazine Executive, 38
description: Peggy Newcomer Pollack, the recently named associate publisher of Mademoiselle magazine, died on Tuesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 38 and lived in Manhattan.

title: From a Night of Rage, the Seeds of Liberation
description: In a time when homosexuality was still widely regarded as a mental illness, when many people shrouded their life style with lies, Dario Modon wore it like velvet.

title: Pancho's Mexican
description: Shares of Pancho's Mexican Buffet Inc. have been trading at $10 to $12 since September. But on Tuesday, after the market closed, Pancho's announced that its third-quarter profit would be a third below Wall Street's estimates of 21 cents a share because of falling sales and rising costs. Shares of Pancho's, which is based in Fort Worth, plunged yesterday.

title: For Carter, a Thrust Onto the Front Pages Again
description: In the 14 years since he left the White House, former President Jimmy Carter has monitored elections, mediated disputes, promoted democracy and worked to eradicate illnesses like Guinea worm disease.

title: Indonesia Shuts Three Outspoken Magazines
description: An era of relative political openness and press freedom in Indonesia appeared to end this week as the Government of President Suharto shut down three influential magazines, including the country's most prominent newsweekly, and warned other publications that they could soon share a similar fate.

title: Canada May Prohibit Entry Of Penthouse's Comic Book
description: Canadian authorities have warned General Media International, the publisher of Penthouse Comix, a Penthouse magazine spinoff, that the August-September issue will not be allowed into Canada unless six panels of comics dealing with the subjugation of women and other sexual themes are changed.

title: Christopher Clarkson, 92, Ex-R.A.F. Pilot
description: Christopher Clarkson, a retired president of American operations for the British Aircraft Corporation, died on Sunday at his home in Old Lyme, Conn. He was 92.

title: San Francisco Shop Makes Acquisition
description: Lewis & Partners, an agency in San Francisco, said yesterday that it had acquired another shop in that city, Hovatter LaPointe Inc., which has been merged into Lewis. The terms were not disclosed.

title: Dollar in Rebound vs. Yen; U.S. Support is Anticipated
description: The dollar rebounded yesterday from its record low against the Japanese yen, as traders speculated that the Clinton Administration would ultimately act to keep the dollar from falling further.

title: How the World Was Built, in 928 Pages
description: IT is the best-selling architectural book in the world, with annual sales in the six-figure range. First published in 1932, the 928-page book, Architectural Graphics Standards, has become, in the words of its current editor, John Hoke Jr., "the Bible of the profession."

title: ALLIANT TECHSYSTEMS TAKES STEPS TO AVOID TAKEOVER
description: Trying to stave off an attempt by a large investor to take control of its board, Alliant Techsystems Inc. said yesterday that it would try to make a "significant acquisition." The company, a munitions manufacturer based in Hopkins, Minn., said in a letter to stockholders that it would also consider a stock repurchase program and a cash dividend. Alliant said it believed an acquisition would be the smartest way to increase stockholder value. The company is challenging a proxy fight initiated earlier this month by Capstay Partners L.P., an investment group, and an affiliate, Gotham Capital III L.P. They are seeking to replace board members and then sell or spin off part of the company. Alliant Techsystems' shares were up 75 cents, at $29.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Unequal Partnership
description: Yesterday, Russia signed the Partnership for Peace plan at NATO's headquarters in Brussels as a step toward closer cooperation with Europe and the United States. Yet there is little agreement here as to whether Russia really needs this program, and what it will gain.

title: The Body as Evidence; Refugees' Wounds Bear Witness to Torture, Supporting Claims for Political Asylum
description: Granville Desousa has an unremarkable scar on his finger, old cuts on his knees, lesions on his limbs and chronic stomach problems.

title: Owen Healthcare Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
For Harding, It's All a Big Act
description: TONYA HARDING has agreed to appear as a feisty waitress in an independent film maker's movie about a woman running from the mob. The Olympic figure skater will play Gina, a waitress who accidentally receives a cache of money from the mob in the movie "Breakaway," written by SEAN DASH and ERIC GARDNER.

title: Teen-Ager Caned in Singapore Returns Home
description: Michael Fay, the teen-ager who was jailed and caned in Singapore for vandalizing cars, returned to his father's home in a Dayton suburb today and was greeted by friends, relatives and an international press corps. Apart from saying, "I feel great, I feel great," Mr. Fay, a 19-year-old high school senior, declined to comment about his experience.

title: G.E. Ousts Kidder, Peabody Chief
description: In an effort to restore the shine to Kidder, Peabody & Company's tarnished image, General Electric yesterday replaced Michael A. Carpenter, Kidder's chief executive, with two senior executives from G.E.

title: A Currency Dragged Down by Twin Deficits
description: With all the talk about the United States economy doing well -- so well that the worry is that it may overheat, why is the dollar hitting record lows against the Japanese yen?

title: O'Rourke Proposes Making Davids Island a County Park
description: Westchester County would buy Davids Island, a long-deserted Army post off the coast of New Rochelle, and convert it into a waterfront park linked to nearby communities by ferry, under a plan proposed today by the County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke.

title: Before the Bar Scene
description: To The Home Section:

title: Union Faults Correction Dept. In Shootout at Kings Hospital
description: A hospital shootout on Tuesday between a prisoner and a New York City correction officer was part of a calculated escape plan that nearly succeeded because of the "inexcusable failures of the Department of Correction," the head of the correction officers union contended yesterday.

title: Accounts
description: * NBC Cable, Fort Lee, N.J., to Kirshenbaum & Bond, New York, as the first agency to handle America's Talking, a cable television network scheduled to begin operating July 4. The agency already handles a sibling cable network, CNBC. Billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million. * Ryan Drossman & Partners, New York, was awarded three accounts with combined billings estimated to exceed $2 million: Sony Theaters/ Loews, New York, to handle the creative portion of its general advertising and the new Sony Imax Theater at Sony Theaters Lincoln Square; Renaissance Carpets and Tapestries, New York, and State-Wide Capital, Uniondale, L.I.

title: Block (H & R) Inc.(HRB,N) reports earnings for Year to Apr 30
description: b-Included gain of $ 27,265,000 from the sale of its Interim Services Inc. unit through an initial public offering, and charge of $ 25,072,000, which is not deductible for income tax purposes, for in-process research and development related to the acquisition of Meca Software Inc.

title: Apogee Enterprises Inc.(APOG,NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: b-After a gain of $ 525,000, or 4 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Just when you thought you could recuperate from the stress of worrying about the Rangers and the Knicks, along comes the Intel Chess Grand Prix, a tournament involving 16 of the top players in the world. The action, to be televised on ESPN, will run from Monday to next Thursday at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, and GARY KASPAROV, the world champion, predicted yesterday that the tension would run every bit as high as what hockey and basketball fans have been experiencing.

title: Archer Cole, New Jersey Leader For Organized Labor, Dies at 77
description: Archer Cole, who spent more than 50 years in the American labor movement, the last 10 as president of the New Jersey Industrial Union Council, died on Saturday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 77 and lived in Roselle, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article yesterday about CBS's negotiations with several college football bowls misidentified the network that broadcasts the Gator Bowl. It is TBS, not ABC.

title:
Market Place;
Recovery in German share prices seems unlikely before autumn.
description: SHARE prices on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange have been in retreat since higher American interest rates created turmoil in global bond markets in mid-May. That turbulence has prompted most experts on German stocks to shift to a very defensive strategy, and few expect any recovery to begin until the autumn.

title: Sports of The Times; Houston Finally Has an Edge
description: CAN fans win a championship? Can the pent-up frustrations of an entire region spur a team on to victory? That is exactly what happened last night in this humid city in south Texas.

title: Falcons Pick Up Matthews
description: Five-time Pro Bowl linebacker CLAY MATTHEWS has reached a one-year contract agreement with the Atlanta Falcons. Matthews, 38, the Cleveland Browns' career leader in sacks (76 1/2), has played in more games (232) than any National Football League linebacker. (AP)

title: Honors
description: * Charlotte Beers, chairwoman and chief executive at Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, New York, received the Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger Award from Barnard College.

title: Yanks Have the City to Themselves
description: Baseball's official calendar may have indicated that the 1994 season started in April. For New Yorkers, it starts today.

title: New Brennan Inquiry Reported in California
description: Robert E. Brennan, the embattled Wall Street financier now facing civil fraud charges in a Manhattan courtroom, also faces problems on another front.

title: After a 40-Year Wait, The Swiss Look Ahead
description: Perhaps it is time the Americans stopped browbeating themselves over that opening-match draw with Switzerland.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: FROM NIGHT OF RAGE, SEEDS OF LIBERATION The Stonewall uprising is widely regarded as the turning point in the gay-rights movement, ushering in an era of pride, openness and activism. But through the eyes of five people who were there that night, the uprising itself was not glamorous. The fact that it has become an icon amazes them still. A1. NEW YORK CITY 48 INDICTED IN GANG WAR OVER DRUG SALES After months of gang warfare for control of half a dozen blocks on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, 48 suspected drug dealers and gunmen were indicted in 8 murders and 13 shootings in a bloody struggle over a neighborhood business that earned $5 million a year. B3.

title: A Change Of Mind That Came Too Late
description: In 1991, four years after he retired from the Supreme Court, I asked Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. if there was any case in which he wished he had voted differently.

title: Rhodes Inc.(RHD,N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Year-ago net, share earnings and shares outstanding are pro forma results if June 1993 initial public offering and recapitalization had been completed at the beginning of 1993 first quarter. Historical first-quarter 1993 loss was $ 1,160,000, or 79 cents a share, based on 1,476,000 outstanding shares.

title: Rockets Hit the Heights as Champions
description: The Rockets took the city of Houston on its first championship ride. The Knicks' quest for glory ended in anguish.

title: If Silver Is Out of Reach, Try Secondhand
description: THIS month, many people who have been purchasing silver for newlyweds or deciding they'd like some for themselves might also be balking at the cost. Though the price of new silver has been stable for the last five years, it remains breathtakingly expensive to the average consumer. A five-piece dinner setting of Georg Jensen Pyramid flatware, for instance, retails for $750 at the Royal Copenhagen Porcelain store on Madison Avenue at 61st Street. Surely it's available, somewhere, for less?

title: CHRONICLE
description: Since the first time he heard YO-YO MA perform more than 15 years ago, JOHN WILLIAMS, the composer of film scores and former conductor of the Boston Pops, has wanted to write a concerto for the cellist.

title: Review/Dance; A Timely Infusion of Shakespeare by Way of Balanchine
description: George Balanchine's humane and humorous "Midsummer Night's Dream" opens up an enchanting world for adults and children alike.

title: Boeing and Airbus Split Big Order
description: Splitting a potentially huge purchase between the Boeing Company and Airbus Industrie, Singapore Airlines said today that it had placed orders and taken options for 52 jetliners worth as much as $10.3 billion.

title: ICF Kaiser International (ICF,N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net lossPer share figures are after preferred dividend payments. Income applicable to common shareholders for the latest period was a loss of $ 321,000, compared with a loss of $ 1,993,000 in 1993.(Loss)

title: Mandela Is Mr. Nice Guy, Irking Some Allies
description: Some imagined that President Nelson Mandela would be Africa's Franklin D. Roosevelt, and a few predicted Fidel Castro. But who ever imagined that the first black President of South Africa would be Mister Rogers?

title:
CURRENTS;
Opening for Home Of Saarinen Family
description: IT was the perfect family project. The house that Eliel Saarinen, the Finnish architect, built in 1930 for himself and his family at the Cranbrook Academy of Art in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., was enriched by the handiwork of all the family members.

title: Arthur H. Gladstein; Dermatologist, 72
description: Dr. Arthur H. Gladstein, an authority on the use of radiation in dermatology, died on Monday at New York University Medical Center. He was 72 and had homes in Searingtown, L.I., and on the Upper East Side.

title: Pledge Made To Give ABC Tax Breaks
description: In the latest pledge of city and state resources to keep a large company in New York City, the ABC Television Network and its corporate parent, Capital Cities Communications, will receive $26 million in sales-tax abatements and subsidized electricity.

title: Airline Gives Family a Crack at Fame
description: Instead of putting up with jokes about lunacy and legumes, families with the last name of Nutt may become recipients of an unanticipated benefit because of a humorous promotion by Continental Airlines.

title: Reports Say Carlesimo Is Heading to Blazers
description: Neither Seton Hall nor the Portland Trail Blazers are commenting on published reports that P. J. Carlesimo is going to jump from the college ranks to become the team's new head coach. Carlesimo has made himself unavailable for comment.

title: Review/Music; Youth's Joy, Age's Wit: 2 Vintages Of Jazz
description: The rewarding jazz double bill through Sunday night at the Blue Note, (131 West Third Street in Greenwich Village) contrasts youthful ambition and agility with mature ebullience and wit. The younger group is a quintet led by the 24-year-old trumpeter Roy Hargrove; it trades sets with the quartet led by the 86-year-old alto saxophonist Benny Carter.

title: Game 7 Pivoted on the Changing of the Guards
description: For nearly an hour after Houston's rousing 90-84 victory over the Knicks tonight, Vernon Maxwell, Kenny Smith and Sam Cassell stood in different corners of a packed, steamy and champagne-soaked locker room, savoring the good vibrations of winning the city's first major championship.

title: Books of The Times; A Flight of Fancy Through the Tobacco Industry
description: Thank You for Smoking By Christopher Buckley 272 pages. Random House. $22.

title: Lawsuit Imperils Double-Deckers' Revival
description: Just three years ago, the first of the British double-decker buses arrived in New York City. Tourists could cruise along on the upper level, the street theater of Manhattan at their feet. They could hop on and off at leisure. The idea caught on.

title: Hartco Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a re-organization at the Department of Energy misidentified the Government laboratory that a safety official said was contaminated with plutonium. It was the Los Alamos National Laboratory in Los Alamos, N.M., not the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in Livermore, Calif.

title: Shorewood Packaging Corp.(SHOR,NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: b-After extraordinary charge of $ 5,206,000, or 29 cents a share, which included a $ 3,098,000 charge related to the refinancing of debt and a $ 2,108,000 charge for the closing of its Farmingdale, N.Y., facility.

title:
CURRENTS;
Special Attention Paid To the Superficial
description: SURFACE is not everything in architecture. But it helps a lot. The exhibition "Architectures of Herzog & de Meuron Photographed by Thomas Ruff," at Peter Blum Gallery, 99 Wooster Street (near Spring Street), shows how modern forms can be given compelling sensuous appeal through impeccably detailed oak panels, local stone set without mortar, or copper banding.

title: Houston Finally Hailing a Champion
description: The Houston Rockets reigned on the court. Disappointment reigned in New York.

title: Two Films, One Subject. Uh-Oh. In Hollywood, the Race Is On.
description: Movie studio executives and producers claim to be on a constant quest for new ideas, but they seem to hunger more for the not-so-new concept. ("Hey, let's make a female 'Fugitive.' ") The more derivative, the better.

title: Mets Take Their War To Braves and Triumph
description: The Mets tried to re-establish order before they played the Braves tonight at Fulton County Stadium. Bret Saberhagen was summoned to meet with Dallas Green and Ed Lynch, the Mets' management representative on this trip. So was John Franco. Some criticisms were forgiven, some inflammatory comments brushed aside.

title: Campus Drinking Problem Becomes Severe; Abuse, Not Addiction
description: To the Editor:

title: 48 Indicted on Warfare Over Drugs on West Side
description: After months of gang warfare for control of half a dozen blocks on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, 48 suspected drug dealers and gunmen were indicted yesterday in 8 murders and 13 shootings in a bloody struggle over a neighborhood business that earned $5 million a year.

title: Fearful Mrs. Simpson Is Heard On Tapes of Emergency Calls
description: An enraged O. J. Simpson broke into the home of his former wife by kicking down her back door one night last October and roared abuse at her as she cowered and wept, according to an audiotape of an emergency telephone call that she was placing to the police.

title: Chest Pains Hospitalize Ditka
description: MIKE DITKA's cardiologist said yesterday that the former Chicago Bears coach was doing fine despite having chest pains the previous day. Ditka was listed in fair condition yesterday at Lake Forest (Ill.) Hospital, where doctors were trying to determine if he had a heart attack.

title: Look Who May Be Going to Boston
description: Hakeem Olajuwon, the Houston Rockets' star center, played soccer growing up in Nigeria and therefore has a strong rooting interest in the World Cup.

title: City Hall Plan To Reshape School System
description: Much of the central administration of the New York City schools -- from the division that buys chalk and pencils to the academy that trains school safety officers -- would be dismantled under a City Hall plan now circulating in draft form.

title: Joy Technologies Inc.(JOY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
description: b-Net income(Loss)Sales are net sales.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The police in Miami have dropped an aggravated assault charge against LUTHER CAMPBELL, the rap artist who was accused of waving a gun at his companion and threatening to kill her, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Review/Pop; Lesbopalooza Celebration
description: Lollapalooza is a traveling summer music festival that defines itself by its diversity and multicultural appeal. But its roster of alternative rock bands and the young, mainly white middle-class following it attracts is representative of only a very small audience. Lesbopalooza, a one-time event that took place on Tuesday night at the Continental defined itself by its lack of breadth and adherence to one theme. But in actuality, Lesbopalooza's seven hours of bands led by women was a diverse parade of talents and styles, attitudes and outlooks.

title: Critic's Notebook Critic's Notebook; On TV, Horror Stories on the Health-Care Front
description: Unlike many of the people featured on "To Your Health" Tuesday night, the man in the audience who complained that his hosts were "making policy by horror stories" was not suffering from ailments his health insurance does not cover. In observing that sad cases were the most dramatic elements of the elaborate two-hour report on NBC, he proved there was nothing wrong with his eyesight.

title: Clinton Says the North Koreans Really May Be Ready for Talks
description: President Clinton said today that he was now satisfied that North Korea is willing to freeze its nuclear program temporarily, and he agreed to open comprehensive talks next month in Geneva.

title: A Win-Win Situation, With the Best Yet to Come
description: Success in horse racing has a kind of Catch-22 quality for a jockey: To win, you have to get good horses; to get good horses, you have to win. And no rider in New York has been solving the equation more frequently than Mike Smith.

title: German Not Guilty of Fire
description: A German judge today found a 19-year-old youth not guilty of setting a fire that destroyed a hostel where asylum-seekers were to be housed.

title: Casey's General Stores Inc.(CASY,NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: All per share amounts adjusted to reflect 2-for-1 stock split, effective Feb. 16, 1994.

title: Retiring Haiti's Junta
description: The Clinton Administration would like to see Haiti's wealthy businesspeople promote a cushy Riviera or Spanish retirement for the three most notorious leaders of Haiti's military regime, and it is freezing all Haitian assets held in U.S. banks to spur them into getting on with the job.

title: Scimed Life Systems Inc.(SMLS,NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Review/Film; A Sexual Awakening, for 2 Generations at Once
description: Alma Gold (Kim Weston-Moran), the title character of Ayoka Chenzira's good-humored coming-of-age film, "Alma's Rainbow," is the straitlaced owner of a beauty parlor who lives with her adolescent daughter, Rainbow (Victoria Gabriella Platt). The daughter, who attends a strict parochial school and studies dance, is just becoming aware of boys. Although Alma has no dearth of suitors, she has fooled herself into believing she has outgrown the need for male companionship. And she sternly advises her daughter to follow her example and keep men at a distance.

title: Lowery Signs With the Jets
description: Ever since kicker Pat Leahy retired two years ago the Jets have been looking for a steady foot. They might have found it yesterday by signing Nick Lowery, the third leading scorer in National Football League history.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NATIONAL HEALTH LABORATORIES INC., La Jolla, Calif., said it had received more than 99 percent of the shares of Allied Clinical Laboratories Inc. Nashville, under its offer of $21.50 a share. NATIONSBANK CORP., Charlotte, N.C., said it would buy the RHNB Corp. and its subsidiary, Rock Hill National Bank, in a tax-free exchange of common stock. Based on Nationsbank's closing price yesterday, the deal would have an estimated value to shareholders of about $44.5 million.

title: Vast Changes Sought in Electric System
description: The two top officers of the New York Power Authority yesterday presented a proposal for a vast restructuring of the state's electric power system. They would form a single company to operate the thousands of miles of transmission lines now owned by the Authority or by the seven investor-owned utilities around the state and another entity to run the six nuclear reactors in the state.

title: Disney's Virginia Park Will Bring American Experience to Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Thompson Shifts On Media Research
description: J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. said yesterday that it had restructured its media research operations by decentralizing them in local offices rather than having them based in the agency's Chicago and New York offices.

title: FRANCE IS SENDING FORCE TO RWANDA TO HELP CIVILIANS
description: France announced today that it would move troops into Rwanda early Thursday to protect civilians against further killings in a conflict that has torn that country apart for more than two months.

title: Bias Policy Widened to Include Gay Students
description: The school board here has unanimously passed a proposal that prohibits discrimination against gay students. The policy is believed to be the first of its kind in a suburban school district in New York State, according to the New York State School Boards Association.

title: Japan Sees Rise of Yen As Threat to Recovery
description: The rise of the yen to its strongest postwar level against the dollar has renewed fears that Japan's export-oriented automobile, electronics and steel companies will suffer another blow to their competitiveness, nipping in the bud Japan's fledgling economic recovery.

title: Dollar Steadies Although U.S. Does Not Intervene
description: As the dollar rebounded slightly today from Tuesday's record low against the Japanese yen, the United States held back from intervening to shore up the American currency. Instead, the Federal Reserve chairman assured investors that the American economy was as healthy as ever, while the Treasury Secretary warned speculators that Washington would act if they tried to push the dollar down further.

title: Team Spirit Is New Message at Olds
description: Blindfolded, about 30 people -- almost all men, many of them middle-aged and portly, and some worth millions -- stumbled through a pasture here, alternately clutching one another's sweaty hands and feeling ahead for trees or oncoming colleagues.

title: Chief of G.M. Unit to Retire
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that Robert T. O'Connell, chairman and chief executive of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, would take early retirement, effective July 1.

title: Man Held in Fatal Arson
description: The police arrested a man yesterday who they said had set fire to an apartment building in Brooklyn, trapping and killing two residents on the top floor. The police said the man was trying to hurt the man who was dating his former girlfriend.

title: Russia and NATO Agree To Closer Military Links
description: In a move intended to begin the process of binding the Russians more firmly to the West, Russia and its former enemy NATO signed an agreement today to forge closer military ties.

title: French Officer Is First Step Toward a Multinational Force
description: The United Nations Security Council voted today to accept an offer by France to send about 2,500 troops to Rwanda as a first step toward deploying a larger multinational force under United Nations control.

title: Nicole Brown Simpson: Slain At the Dawn of a Better Life
description: For nearly half her life, Nicole Brown Simpson was known as O. J. Simpson's girlfriend, his wife, then his ex-wife. But in her last days, after she had broken off their efforts to get back together, she had been struggling to be Nicole Brown.

title: Working Hard for the Money
description: Hakeem Olajuwon's parents weren't on hand to watch their son play in the most important game of his career. Salaam and Abike Olajuwon had intended to be courtside since Game 1 but instead have contented themselves with watching on television.

title: Earth Technology Deal
description: The Earth Technology Corporation has agreed to acquire Hazwaste Industries for 2.3 million shares of Earth Technology stock valued at about $29 million. Hazwaste, a closely held company based in Richmond, specializes in environmental remediation services. It had 1993 revenue of $50 million. Earth Technology provides environmental consulting services for government and industry.

title: MDS Health reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: MDS said that its class B shareholders are entitled to an additional 2.5 cents dividend a share a year, by means of a noncumulative dividend, over any dividends paid on the A shares. It said that no deduction for these additional dividends has been made in the calculation of basic earnings per share.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: German Socialists Name Choice For Uphill Battle Against Kohl
description: The German opposition Social Democratic Party, reeling from a steep drop in popularity in recent weeks, officially nominated Rudolf Scharping today as its candidate for Chancellor, and Mr. Scharping responded with a fighting speech that brought him loud cheers.

title: Calendar: Design Talks, Exhibitions and a Sale
description: Gay and Lesbian Forum Cooper Union's Great Hall, 7 East Seventh Street; (212) 969-8773.

title: A Killing Divides Kashmiris Seeking Freedom
description: The assassination of an influential Muslim cleric in Kashmir has drawn angry protests and prompted an investigation by pro-independence religious and political leaders.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball National League

title: Executive Quits Digital
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation has lost its third top executive in as many months. The company said today that Adriana Stadecker, vice president of executive operations in the office of the president at Digital, had resigned to form Epic International, Executive Partners in Change, a consulting firm in Newton, Mass.

title: Stop & Shop Cos.(SHP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 21
description: b-Included extraordinary loss of $ 1,724,000, or 3 cents a share, for premiums and noncash write-offs of unamortized deferred financing costs related to extinguishment of debt.c-After a charge of $ 10,691,000, or 21 cents a share, for the adoption of FASB 106 and a change in the method of accounting with regard to the discount rate used for certain self-insurance and other liabilities.

title: Government Panel Hears Call For Expanded AIDS Testing
description: More people need to be tested for the virus that causes AIDS, even if it means using such unconventional approaches as letting them do it themselves at home, former Surgeon General C. Everett Koop testified today.

title: Pension Rules Threaten Police Chief's Job
description: These are trying times for Neil A. Polay, a retired New York City police lieutenant who is the new Police Chief here.

title: Essay; See-Nothing Congress
description: "I only picked up the phone," said the judge, not all that happy to be speaking to a columnist, "because the secretary is out to lunch and my clerk is in labor."

title: New Democrats, Old Cynicism
description: Everyone remembers Bill Clinton's multiple promises that when he got to the White House he would elevate Washington's moral tone by changing the rules of the capital's influence game. Yet his own party has worked mightily to keep the old system alive. And Mr. Clinton himself has yet to press hard for his proposals to clean up a campaign financing system that binds lawmakers to special interests.

title: Univar Corp.(UVX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included expenses of $ 2.1 million, or 10 cents a share, for its program to re-engineer operations.

title: Treasury Bonds Post Sharp Gains
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose sharply yesterday as a result of a rebounding dollar against the yen and three consecutive days of decline in commodity futures prices.

title: Review/Music; Xenakis Program Cuts Through the Mystery
description: It may have been fortunate that the copying machine broke down at Thread Waxing Space on Tuesday night, because the audience was spared from seeing the program of the ST-X Ensemble Xenakis USA. All the compositions were by the group's namesake, Iannis Xenakis, and all bore cryptic titles -- some drawn from the ancient Greek -- that might have put listeners off: "Khalperr," "Epei," "Anaktoria" and "Waarg." Had explanatory notes from the composer been available, the result would have been still more bewildering.

title: Lennar Corp.(LEN,N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After two one-time accounting adjustments in the first quarter which increased net earnings by $ 961,000, or 3 cents a share.During the first quarter 1994, the company adopted Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 109, ''Accounting For Income Taxes'', which reflected a gain of $ 4,745,000, and this was offset by a charge of $ 3,784,000, from a change in accounting for purchased mortgage servicing rights, reflecting a change in the way in which the company values that asset from an undiscounted cash flow to a discounted cash flow measurement.

title: Leadership Race in the Senate Attracting Mainly Spectators
description: A struggle is raging across Capitol Hill this summer for one of the most eminent and visible posts in politics. Not that anyone can tell, though.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Selig Chides Players Union
description: Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, yesterday issued a statement in which he chided the Players Association for its involvement in the attempt by some United States senators to strip baseball of its exemption from the antitrust law as it pertains to labor relations. But the owners also just might be jittery about the outcome of a vote in Washington today.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article from the United Nations on Tuesday about France's plan to send troops to Rwanda misidentified Faustin Twagiramungu. He is the Prime Minister-designate of Rwanda, not an official of the rebel Rwandan Patriotic Front.

title: INSIDE
description: Russia Conceals Arms Effort

title: An Estate Stars As a Spanish Palace
description: HIGHLAND MILLS , N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about testimony by Dr. David A. Kessler, the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, that the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation had developed a genetically engineered tobacco plant misstated the effect of the development. The genetic engineering doubled the amount of nicotine in the tobacco, not the amount in cigarettes made from it and other tobaccos.

title: Gunfire Kills Woman and Wounds Her Infant Son
description: An 18-year-old mother holding her infant son was shot to death yesterday outside her Brooklyn home by a gunman who was apparently aiming at someone else. The baby and two men, including one who may have been the intended victim, were also shot.

title: Prof. Einar Ingvald Haugen, 88, Expert on Scandinavian Culture
description: Einar Ingvald Haugen, a professor of Scandinavian language and literature, died on Monday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 88.

title: Review/Opera; For 'Falstaff,' the Stage Becomes a Period Barn
description: When Richard Gaddes founded the Opera Theater of St. Louis, in 1976, his plan was to create a modified Glyndebourne in the Midwest. The atmosphere would be genial and festive, with dinner on the lawn before the opera. The repertory would draw heavily on contemporary works and neglected 18th- and 19th-century scores, with familiar works as the icing rather than the cake. The operas would be sung in English, mostly by young Americans. And the house -- the 950-seat Loretto-Hilton Center -- would be intimate enough for the singers to be heard and understood without forcing.

title: Youth Is Convicted in Murder for a Bicycle
description: A Brooklyn teen-ager was convicted of murder yesterday in the killing ofAllyn Winslow, 42, a drama teacher who was shot in the back last June as a groupof teen-agers tried to steal his bicycle in Prospect Park.

title: Radical Answer to a Small College's Woes
description: In an aggressive effort to remedy ills common to many of the nation's small liberal arts colleges, Bennington College is reducing tuition, trimming its staff and eliminating tenure.

title: Long-Sought Title That Ewing Needed Eludes Him Again
description: Patrick Ewing needed it more. He needed championship validation more than Hakeem Olajuwon. He needed it because it has always been so much easier for people to doubt him, to blame him for who he was or who he wasn't.

title: Body and Soul: United States Pulls Off a Minor Miracle
description: American soccer desperately needed a moment this exalted and galvanizing, something that would urgently lift the game from the back burner to the front of the country's sporting consciousness.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: A Water Garden Barrel

title: Starks Builds His Nightmare Brick by Brick
description: After all the stops on a long road, after the bold trip through the anonymity of basketball's minor leagues all the way to the game of his career, John Starks said he never experienced anything close to what happened tonight. On a night for a game to remember, his was one to forget.

title: McDonald's and Hotels Plan Food Delivery Test
description: In a test that could begin as early as next week, McDonald's will begin delivering food to guest rooms at about 40 budget hotels in 20 cities across the country.

title: Park Electrochemical Corp.(PKE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
Health Data Chief Settles With S.E.C.
description: The chairman and chief executive of the Shared Medical Systems Corporation admitted in Federal court yesterday to charges of insider trading -- and then promptly denied he had done any such thing.

title: Adopted Youths Are Normal In Self-Esteem, Study Finds
description: A new study of adopted adolescents and their families has found that contrary to popular belief, the adopted teen-agers were no more likely than other adolescents to suffer from mental health or identity problems.

title: Robert L. Bates; Geologist, 82
description: Robert L. Bates, a geologist who was a teacher, science writer and editor, died on Tuesday at Riverside Hospital in Columbus, Ohio. He was 82 and lived in Columbus.

title: Baton Broadcasting reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Firan Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: AT HOME WITH: E. Annie Proulx; At Midlife, a Novelist Is Born
description: DON'T get Annie Proulx wrong. She is pleased, happy, thrilled beyond words about winning the Pulitzer Prize this year for her second novel, "The Shipping News." For one thing, she loves soft-shell crabs, which are not available in Vermont. Lately, she has been flying to New York and has been taken to restaurants that serve them.

title: Stich Stunned by Shelton on the Court of Upsets
description: Michael Stich was already grouchy about being assigned to Court 2, the shady dell that gained its nickname as Wimbledon's graveyard court by playing host to upsets of a Who's Who of former champions that includes Jimmy Connors, Arthur Ashe and John McEnroe.

title: Review/Theater; Retelling Of Life's Abashing Moments
description: Lisa Kron, the inspired creator of the one-woman show "101 Humiliating Stories," hates it when she gets sleepy in the theater, especially if she's onstage. So there's the inevitable point, befitting a performance where the star wears pajamas, when her eyelids grow leaden and her head so heavy that she bumps it against a lamp. She wakens to recall a childhood dream that was so realistic it influenced her behavior in school the next day; its unfortunate consequences will be familiar to anyone who remembers the social mores of second-grade friendships.

title: Yankees Roll a 7 And Get A Sweep
description: Ten minutes. That is how long the Yankees let the Twins enjoy the one-run lead Minnesota had crawled to secure before New York destroyed it. Eleven hitters. That is how many Yankees rushed to swing a bat in an unexpected and eventful seventh inning. Twelve months ago. That is the last time the Yankees had orchestrated a series sweep of the Twins.

title: Sweden Goalie Joins Islanders
description: Goaltender TOMMY SALO, who stopped Canada's PAUL KARIYA in a sudden-death shootout to give Sweden the 1992 Olympic gold medal, has agreed to terms with the Islanders. Salo, 23, selected in the fifth round of the 1993 N.H.L. entry draft, also played in the world championships and for Vasteras in the Swedish Elite League. (AP)

title: Culp Inc.(CULP,NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
description: All per-share figures have been adjusted to reflect the 3-for-2 stock split distributed in January 1994 and the 5-for-4 stock split distributed in July 1993.

title: Super Rite Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: Year-ago first quarter's results were restated to reflect an accounting treatment for a contingent stock option.Super Rite is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Illinois Health Facilities Authority is selling $76.08 million of revenue bonds through First Chicago Capital Markets. The bonds are priced to yield a maximum of 6.40 percent for an issue due in 2014, with shorter- maturity serial bonds priced to yield from 4.40 percent in 1996 to 6.15 percent in 2009. All the bonds are rated triple-A by Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Service because they are insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corp. * Taubman Realty Group Ltd., Bloomfield Hills, Mich., is selling $200 million of 8 percent notes due in 1999 at 99.954 to yield 8.01 percent through Morgan Stanley. The noncallable issue is rated Baa2 by Moody's and BBB+ by S.& P.

title: Nordica Selects Morey Mahoney
description: Nordica U.S.A. Inc., a unit of the Italian company Benetton, said yesterday that it had selected Morey Mahoney Advertising in Denver to handle advertising for its Nordica and Kastle Alpine ski products in North America, previously handled by Jager di Paola Kemp in Burlington, Vt., for a year and a half. Billings were not disclosed.

title: U.S. Investments Overseas Benefit From Dollar's Drop
description: The dollar has dropped substantially this year against both the yen and the mark, but for an increasing number of Americans who invest overseas, it has been a real boon. That is because as the dollar has declined against other currencies, investments in overseas assets have become more valuable.

title: 3 Governors Take Pleas On Aliens to the Senate
description: Armed with metaphors equating illegal immigration with natural disasters, the Governors of California, Florida and Arizona beseeched the Senate Appropriations Committee today for reimbursement for services that their states provide illegal aliens.

title: The Pop Life
description: New Leaf for Gangster Rap

title: Jerusalem Journal; No Middle of the Road for Israel's Driven Politics
description: On the Israeli right, which emphatically says no to giving up land to the Arabs, Gilon Ben-Said is about as politically correct as one can get. For sure, his car is.

title: Disney Licenses Characters for Multimedia
description: America's favorite mouse has a multimedia future.

title: Anselm Talalay, 82, Inventor and Official
description: Anselm Talalay, an inventor and retired vice president of research and development at the B.F. Goodrich Industrial Products Division in Akron, Ohio., died on Thursday at his home in Cleveland. He was 82.

title: Phyllis Shorenstein, 76, Patron Of Asian Arts in San Francisco
description: Phyllis J. Shorenstein, a founder of the Asian Art Museum of San Francisco, died on Wednesday at the University of California at San Francisco Medical Center. She was 76 and lived in San Francisco.

title: Dodgers Send Dreifort to the Minors
description: The rookie right-hander DARREN DREIFORT, who began his professional career with the Los Angeles Dodgers without pitching in the minor leagues, was optioned to San Antonio of the Texas League yesterday.

title: Ohio State Gets One Year of Probation
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association placed Ohio State on one year probation yesterday and stripped it of a scholarship because of recruiting violations in men's basketball. The governing body of college athletics also said Coach RANDY AYERS will not be permitted to leave campus during the July and September recruiting periods this year.

title: An Upset Kick-Starts American Confidence For the Long Run
description: Was this a miracle on grass?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief article yesterday about a teen-ager's conviction for felony murder in the killing of a bicyclist in Prospect Park described the rules on sentencing juvenile offenders incorrectly in some editions. Although in this case the defendant could not be sentenced in State Supreme Court, because the felony murder charge accompanied only a charge of attempted robbery, the law does allow 14- or 15-year-old defendants in some cases to be sentenced in Supreme Court, where penalties are harsher than in Family Court.

title: Prices of Pork Bellies Drop On Frozen Storage Report
description: Prices of pork bellies plunged yesterday after the Department of Agriculture reported a growing supply of frozen pork bellies in storage.

title: Japan Leader Faces Move To Oust Him
description: After two months in office that were marked by near total political paralysis, Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata faces a no-confidence vote in coming days that threatens to bring down his minority Government.

title: Emerging Plan Is Still Costly, Still Complex
description: The health care proposal being developed within the Senate Finance Committee, like President Clinton's plan, is technically complicated, difficult to administer and expensive, health policy experts said today.

title: Art in Review
description: Nic Nicosia PPOW Gallery 532 Broadway (near Spring Street) SoHo Through July 15

title: Penalty Time Mystery Solved
description: Americans are asking: What's with this injury time?

title: Cutbacks Peril Miami's Citizenship Events
description: Immigrants who come here in search of wealth have encountered another sign that the streets are not paved with gold: the Government has run out of money for the swearing-in ceremonies at which new Americans take the oath of citizenship.

title: Rabbi, a Town Official, Is Accused of Taking Bribe for Power-Plant Approval
description: An Orthodox rabbi who is also the chairman of the planning and zoning adjustment boards in Lakewood Township was indicted today by an Ocean County grand jury on charges that he took $500,000 to help win political approval of a power plant there.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; For gay consumers, sales pitches are getting more personal.
description: THE fledgling trend of mainstream marketers aiming sales pitches at gay and lesbian consumers is evolving to more specialized levels.

title:
DIALOGUE: Can Talks With North Korea Succeed?;
3 Myths May Foil Progress
description: Now that high-level talks between the United States and North Korea are to resume next month, three myths that have haunted the U.S. debate over the nuclear crisis for two years need to be dispelled for good. If they are not, the protracted negotiations ahead are likely to founder.

title: Olajuwon Is Savoring Experience Of Victory
description: With a group of friends and fans looking on, Hakeem Olajuwon today accepted the National Basketball Association finals most valuable player award for leading the Houston Rockets to their first championship.

title: Korean Talks: Looking for Options
description: Now that the North Koreans and the United States have finally agreed to hold high-level negotiations, the Clinton Administration confronts a difficult problem: defining what the talks are supposed to accomplish and how.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 12 about the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts referred imprecisely to a foundation donation to the Studio in a School Association, a fine arts program founded by Agnes Gund. Of the $500,000 donation, only $50,000 was authorized while Ms. Gund was a board member of the Warhol Foundation. The rest was authorized in April 1989, shortly before Ms. Gund joined an advisory committee to the foundation and a year before she joined its board.

title: HEALTH COALITION STRONGLY OPPOSES COMPROMISE PLAN
description: A broad coalition of labor, civic and consumer groups today mounted an attack against the compromise national health insurance plan emerging in the Senate Finance Committee.

title: At the Bar; Lawyers jockey for a piece of O. J. action on TV or in court.
description: Call it the Roone Arledge-ization of the law. All over the airwaves, Los Angeles lawyers are doing for the O. J. Simpson case what Mr. Simpson once did for football: analyzing, second-guessing, prognosticating, handicapping, Monday morning quarterbacking.

title: Home Video
description: Fate of Videotape

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day on Wednesday about American Flywheel Systems Inc.'s development of electric cars described the cars' power source incorrectly in some editions. It is to be spinning flywheels that produce electricity; it is not "bomb fuel."

title: Trenton Court Assails '88 Trial of Day-Care Aide
description: Saying that the interrogation of child witnesses in her trial was tainted, the New Jersey Supreme Court today upheld an appellate ruling that freed a former preschool teacher, Margaret Kelly Michaels, who was convicted six years ago in one of the most notorious child sexual abuse cases in the nation.

title: Clinton Tries to Head Off Senate on Bosnia Embargo
description: The Clinton Administration began a furious diplomatic and lobbying campaign today to head off a Senate bill that orders the President to ignore the United Nations and unilaterally end United States participation in the arms embargo against Bosnia.

title: Officer Threatens Suicide
description: A New York City police officer sat on the front steps of City Hall early today, put a gun to her head and threatened suicide, the police said, leading to a tense standoff with hostage negotiators.

title: European Leaders to Choose New Top Official
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia has been espied aboard a Greek shipping magnate's yacht in the azure seas around this tourist-laden isle. Scandinavian ministers plan to dance around a maypole at midnight in a belated celebration of the summer solstice.

title: Top Horses to Renew Rivalries At Belmont and Atlantic City
description: Some of the star horses in the Belmont barns were working out yesterday to renew rivalries in two states this weekend and to raise the curtain on the second half of the racing year.

title: U.S. Offices of Hong Kong Commodities Firm Are Seized
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has closed down the offices of an unregistered commodities trading company based in Hong Kong that the commission fears cheated about 1,000 investors out of millions of dollars.

title: AT THE MET WITH: Brice Marden; A Tour That Moves From Calligraphy to Pollock
description: BACK in the 1960's, Brice Marden first made a name for himself painting monochrome gray panels that were spartan, implacable, silent. Today Mr. Marden is waiting at the round information desk in the lobby of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in black jeans, black shirt and black baseball cap. With a nod rather than a hello, followed by a long silence, he is as subdued as his dress.

title: Port-au-Prince Journal; Is Voodoo the Weapon To Repel the Invaders?
description: With the threat of foreign intervention hanging over Haiti, the de facto president, Emil Jonassaint, appeared on television last week to rally nationalist sentiment and warn attackers of the secret weapons he said his country held in reserve.

title: Woman Burned in Dispute
description: A man threw a flammable liquid on his girlfriend then set her afire after an argument in Brooklyn last night, the police said.

title: Chart House
description: Chart House Enterprises, a restaurant chain, said after the market closed on Wednesday that it expected second-quarter earnings to fall below analysts' estimates of 25 cents a share, to 14 cents to 18 cents a share. Trading in the stock was delayed yesterday because of an order imbalance. An analyst for CS First Boston also cut her recommendation to "hold" from "strong buy."

title: Art in Review
description: Beverly Semmes Michael Klein 594 Broadway (at Houston Street) SoHo Through next Thursday

title: School Report Draws Doubts From Cortines
description: Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines expressed skepticism yesterday about a preliminary City Hall plan to dismantle the central school bureaucracy and delegate some of its functions to the city's 32 community school districts.

title: Critic's Choice/Film; Precursor of 'Passion,' And Other Italian Treats
description: The timing couldn't be better for a revival of Ettore Scola's "Passione d'Amore," the 1981 movie that inspired "Passion," the new musical by Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine. The film, which opens the Joseph Papp Public Theater's 1994 Italian Summer Festival tonight at 8:05, is remarkably similar in look and pacing to the Broadway musical adaptation except for one crucial difference. The character of Fosca, the ugly, ailing woman who conceives an obsessive passion for Giorgio, a handsome 19th-century cavalry officer, was softened for the Broadway musical.

title: Fund's Rating in Question
description: The BankAmerica Corporation is paying the price for offering higher yields on its money market funds, in part through the use of volatile investments called derivatives.

title: TV Weekend; Extraterrestrials and Earthlings Who Know Them
description: Apparently leery of everyday realities that might discomfort viewers, Rupert Murdoch's Fox Broadcasting is increasingly fond of diversions into the supernatural and paranormal. The evolving network had surprising success this past season with "The X Files," a drama series featuring two F.B.I. agents investigating cases that defy reason, and usually believability. Tonight at 8, the latest Fox excursion into paranormal phenomena can be found on a new magazine series (it was given a sneak preview in February) called "Encounters: The Hidden Truth."

title: On My Mind; The Press and Simpson
description: Among the scores of millions of Americans who watched the Simpson story play out on TV and read about it in the papers were every reporter, commentator, editor and publisher in the country.

title: INSIDE
description: 'Quality of Life' Crackdown

title: Life Insurer Bests G.E. On Kemper
description: Conseco Inc., an upstart life insurer, challenged the General Electric Company to a bidding war for the Kemper Corporation yesterday, but General Electric decided to retreat from the field.

title: Justice Department Is Reviewing Inquiry Into Teamsters Leader
description: Justice Department officials have begun an internal investigation to determine whether Federal prosecutors in Manhattan properly investigated allegations that Ron Carey, head of the international teamsters' union, was linked to organized-crime figures, a spokesman for Attorney General Janet Reno said yesterday.

title: Dykstra Out After Appendicitis Surgery
description: Phillies center fielder LENNY DYKSTRA was listed in good condition yesterday at a Philadelphia hospital after undergoing surgery for appendicitis. Dr. PHILLIP MARONE, the Phillies' team doctor, estimated Dykstra would be out two to three weeks, which could keep last season's runner-up for the National League most valuable player award out of the lineup until after the All-Star Game break.

title: Review/Music; Master and Pupils Mesh As Solti Project Concludes
description: The 81-year-old Georg Solti has opened himself to attack with recent statements about the problems caused for American orchestras and aspiring players by the striking down of mandatory retirement clauses. Yet he speaks a truth that few of less venerable stature would dare to utter. And he put that stature to further use in the last two weeks by providing a showcase for young American-trained musicians in the Solti Orchestral Project at Carnegie Hall.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: SPEAKER WHEELS AND DEALS ON BUDGET

title: Good Looks, and Dreams of the Stylish Life
description: In the fast-lane life that flows along San Vicente Boulevard in the Brentwood section here, Ronald Lyle Goldman moved with a youthful grace that turned heads even amid the opulence and glamour.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on June 15 about a group of Los Angeles high school students who formed a company called Food From the 'Hood misstated their financial benefits. The company has set a limit of $45,000 in scholarships that any student can earn, but it has not projected that any current students will earn that much.

title: Healing Children, Can Bosnia Heal Itself
description: To reignite the spirit of 8-year-old Adnan Mujkanovic, his mother says, it has taken five months without exploding shells, a lot of cuddling and a move from a shell-scarred high-rise just off Sarajevo's western battlefront to a central-city apartment.

title: For Children
description: Sony Wonder Technology Lab Sony Plaza 550 Madison Avenue (at 56th Street) (212) 833-5414 Recommended ages: 4 and up

title: France's Risky Rwanda Plan
description: For want of a better offer, the United Nations has warily authorized France to send troops to try to quell the ethnic massacres in Rwanda. It is an anomalous bid, since it was France that originally armed and trained the very Hutu-led "government" militias that are credibly accused of slaughtering minority Tutsis. Though the U.S. delegate praised France's "bold" and "noble offer," it has been generally opposed by human rights and humanitarian groups, and has been assailed by the rebel Patriotic Front, whose leaders are mostly Tutsis.

title: Terry Murray Hired to Coach the Flyers
description: The Philadelphia Flyers yesterday named the former Washington Capitals coach and former Flyers defenseman TERRY MURRAY as the team's head coach.

title: Are Lawyers Compulsive, Or Just Nicely Precise?
description: Lawyers are compulsive creatures where language is concerned, instinctively treating even the placement of a comma as if it could destroy an entire legal document. "We can be precise to a fault, but that's because precision is essential in a transaction," said Sherry F. Colb, an assistant professor of law at the Rutgers University School of Law in Camden. "After all, you are binding yourself and your client to something specific. You want that something to be absolutely correct."

title: U.S. to Resume Anti-Drug Flights Over 2 Latin Nations; Talks in Colombia
description: With American officials in Washington expressing anger over the "narco tape" scandal here, the United States Ambassador met secretly for two hours today with the Colombian president-elect.

title: Race for Governor: Cuomo Focuses on Accomplishments
description: CANDIDATE: Mario M. Cuomo

title: Shooting Prompts a Review of Prisoner Policy
description: The City Department of Correction said yesterday it was reviewing its system for classifying "high risk" prisoners, two days after an inmate -- a robbery suspect who was not considered high risk under the current policy -- snatched a correction officer's gun and critically wounded another officer at Kings County Hospital.

title: First Data Raises Western Union Bid
description: The First Data Corporation raised its offer for the New Valley Corporation's Western Union unit yesterday to $660 million, topping by $10 million a surprise bid for the company made last week by the buyout firm Forstmann Little & Company.

title: U.S. to Revive Flights to Help Latin Nations Combat Drugs
description: Reversing a decision that drew heavy criticism, the Clinton Administration plans to resume intelligence-gathering flights over the Andes that provide information to Colombia and Peru about planes that smuggle drugs.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Reviving the Independent Counsel
description: Congress has finally voted to revive the independent counsel law, one of the most valuable reforms that followed the Watergate scandal. President Clinton, who campaigned as a fan of the law but is himself now the subject of an investigation, is expected to sign the bill.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Yes, Change the School Lunch Menu, but Also Teach Nutrition; Grow Your Own Food
description: To the Editor:

title: American Love Affair With the Auto May Doom Magnetic Rail
description: To the Editor:

title: Children's Unit For Publisher
description: Time Warner Audiobooks announced today that it was starting a children's division.

title: New Signs Of Slowdown In Economy
description: Fresh evidence of a decelerating economy appeared today as a moderate overall rise in new orders for durable goods was accompanied by the fourth consecutive decline in orders for equipment to be used by nonmilitary manufacturers.

title: Council Chief Wheels and Deals, And New York's Budget Is Passed
description: In the hours before the City Council voted yesterday to approve New York City's new budget, Council Speaker Peter F.
