Jergens said it would unbundle the account after leaving Publicis/Bloom, but it did not identify the agencies being considered for the creative portion. Billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: Dollar Falls Against Yen
description: The dollar again fell below 100 Japanese yen today as some Tokyo banks sold off their dollar holdings. In early trading, the dollar hit 99.90 yen, before bouncing up slightly. By late afternoon, the dollar was quoted at 100.21 yen, up from 99.93 yen in Tokyo on Monday, but down from 100.45 yen in later trading in New York. "Large lot selling from a Tokyo bank triggered the dollar's decline," one analyst said. The renewed weakness in the dollar also prompted a selloff in United States Treasury bonds here.

title: Johnson Buys Stake in Dream and Lakers
description: MAGIC JOHNSON realized his long-held dream to own part of a National Basketball Association team, buying a stake in the Los Angeles Lakers, the team announced yesterday.

title: German Inflation Down
description: Consumer price inflation in western Germany slowed to 2.9 percent in June, preliminary figures showed, down from 3 percent in May, though economists warned of a likely upward revision when the final figures come out in mid-July. Consumer prices in western Germany rose a preliminary one-tenths of 1 percent in the month through mid-June and were up 2.9 percent from a year earlier, the Federal Statistics Office said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a major suspect's decision to cooperate with the prosecution in a terrorist conspiracy trial in New York next fall misstated the role of Earl Gant, a minor figure in the case. In pleading guilty to a lesser charge recently, Mr. Gant reached an agreement with the Government that he would not be required to testify against any other defendant; the point was not left in doubt.

title: ARROW ELECTRONICS TO ACQUIRE DISTRIBUTOR
description: Arrow Electronics Inc., a distributor of semiconductors and other electronic parts, agreed yesterday to acquire Gates/FA Distributing Inc. for about $142 million in stock. Arrow, based in Melville, L.I., will offer $22.50 in stock for each of the 6.3 million shares of Gates/FA, an electronics distributor in Greenville, S.C. Shares of Gates/FA climbed $2.50, to $20.50, on volume of almost 1.8 million shares in Nasdaq trading. Arrow shares gained 37.5 cents, to $35.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. The acquisition will increase Arrow's presence among so-called value-added resellers, who customize hardware and software for specific businesses. Value-added resellers have slightly better profit margins than standard distributors.

title: Agassi's Comeback Can't Catch Martin
description: Off went his final shot of the match right where he didn't want it go, wide of the sideline. Off went his shirt into the crowd, just one of the many ritual gestures that have made him the darling of Wimbledon before, during and after his 1992 triumph here. Up stood those unimpressionable folks in the Royal Box, giving him a standing ovation rather than a stiff upper lip, and then off went Andre Agassi where nobody except Todd Martin wanted him to go, home to Las Vegas.

title: Killer of 6 Is Sentenced to Prison
description: In a court session marked by screams of rage from his victims' relatives, Ramon Concepcion, a Bronx man who pleaded guilty to killing his girlfriend, her three children, her mother and her mother's companion, was sentenced yesterday in New York State Supreme Court to 37 1/2 years in prison.

title: High Court Bars School District Created to Benefit Hasidic Jews
description: The Supreme Court today declared unconstitutional a public school district that New York State created for the benefit of a village of ultra-Orthodox Jews.

title: Why Oz Is a State of Mind In Gay Life and Drag Shows
description: Consider this scenario: A teen-ager, growing up in a drab, flat part of the Midwest that is strictly American Gothic, feels out of place and misunderstood and fantasizes about a more colorful, exotic world. Well, the kid finds that world: a land of magnificent artifice filled with strange, enchanting companions, all united by a pungent feeling of incompleteness. The kid has many exciting adventures but continues to yearn with a bottomless pang for the idea of something called home.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League BALTIMORE ORIOLES -- Placed Sid Fernandez, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to June 19. Recalled Arthur Rhodes, pitcher, from Rochester of the International League.

title: Lawyer-Client Issue Rises In Bomb Conspiracy Case
description: Lawyers representing the men charged with plotting to bomb New York City landmarks demanded yesterday to meet with a judge on how a crucial defendant's reported move toward cooperating with prosecutors could affect defense strategies of others charged in the case.

title: Chinese Stock Offering
description: The Shandong Huaneng Power Development Company of China filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell as many as 1.16 billion shares in a global stock offering. The company, which owns electric power generating plants in Shandong province, plans to sell the stock as American depository shares, with each of those shares representing 50 ordinary shares. A total of 23.3 million depository shares will be issued. Shandong Huaneng hopes to sell the depository shares at $13 to $17 each, according to the S.E.C. filing. At $17, the offering would bring in $397.3 million.

title: Jess B. Bessinger Jr.; English Professor, 72
description: Jess B. Bessinger Jr., a retired professor of English at New York University who was an expert on Beowulf, the longest poem surviving in Old English, died on Thursday in his home in Middletown, R.I. He was 72.

title: Where Meetings Are Truly Feared
description: These are scary times for some corporate executives in Japan, and not just because of the depressed economy and the strong yen. Consider the case of Juntaro Suzuki, a senior managing director for the Fuji Photo Film Company.

title: Excerpts From Opinions And Dissent on Religion
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today in Board of Education v. Grumet, declaring unconstitutional the public school district that New York State established for a community of Satmar Hasidim. Justice David H. Souter's majority opinion was joined by Justices Harry A. Blackmun, John Paul Stevens, Sandra Day O'Connor, and Ruth Bader Ginsburg. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy concurred separately. Justice Antonin Scalia dissented in an opinion that was also signed by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justice Clarence Thomas. FROM THE DECISION By Justice Souter

title: Germany Holds Off South Korea
description: The first half of this Group C match today went according to form, with the defending World Cup champion German team all but squashing the quick but inexperienced South Korean team, which has never won a cup game.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: TROUBLES WITH TEACHER TENURE

title: Review/Fashion; A Collection in Every Port
description: A decade ago, European fashion manufacturers were mystified by what was called the cruise-resort season in the United States. Now, they've all caught on. In the last week, most important designers have shown a cruise collection, to reach the stores in November and December. Some have even tested new ideas.

title: Who Knows The Rules? Embarrassed U.S. Didn't
description: The American players are not out of the World Cup, but they are out of sorts: with each other, with the coaches, with team officials.

title: Fast? Furious? Chess, ESPN Style
description: Alexey Vyzmanavin and Pedrag Nikolic, grandmasters in the world of chess, sat facing each other on either side of a tiny table and arm-wrestled with their minds. Now and then one would deftly move a rook or a pawn, but beyond that, most of the action consisted of back-arching, face-rubbing and, once, Mr. Nikolic pulled an ear, his own.

title: You Can't Roller-Skate On Electronic Highway
description: THERE are now an estimated 25 million people on the Internet, 6 million or so on commercial computer networks like Prodigy and Compuserve and perhaps 20 million more on local area networks within businesses.

title: Sports of The Times; A Slice Of Sports In Drag
description: GAY GAMES IV are gone from New York, but they have left an indelible, colorful imprint, and not just pink. Other hues are red, white and blue.

title: A Puzzling Strength Amid Turmoil
description: As the Japanese yen soared above a crucial benchmark today, the incongruities here seemed even more striking: How could Japan's currency be so strong when its economy is still scraping bottom and its once seamless political order has unraveled for the third time in a year?

title: Uneven Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BATTERED DOLLAR: THE IMPACT A Primer on the Dollar; The Currency's Well-Publicized Decline Hasn't Meant Much for Most Americans
description: Ten years ago, a dollar bought 250 Japanese yen; a month ago, it bought just 105. Now, it buys about 100.

title: Cellstar Corp.(CLST,NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Cellstar said that its increased revenue in the second quarter and six months was primarily the result of ''continued strong domestic wholesale sales of cellular telephones.''

title: Vivra Inc.(V,N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included extraordinary gain of $ 697,000, or 3 cents a share, on sale of discontinued operations.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 163,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 247,000, or 1 cent a share, in the 6 months.Vivra said that the figures for discontinued operations from last year are from Personal Care Health Services, its home health care nursing business, which the company sold in December.Per-share figures reflected a 3-for-2 stock split in November.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the publication of diaries attributed to Benito Mussolini misstated the wartime role of the father of the man who made the diaries public. The father, who concealed the diaries until his death in 1962, served in the guerrilla unit that captured and executed Mussolini, but was not its leader.

title: A Mistake and Then a Disaster
description: A Map of the World By Jane Hamilton 390 pages. Doubleday. $22.

title: The White House Turns Again To an Old G.O.P. Image-Maker
description: In an interview last November, David R. Gergen made clear that he wanted to be regarded as a man of substance, not spin.

title: Japanese Put a Human Face on Computers
description: A VISITOR to Akikazu Takeuchi's office at the Sony Computer Science Laboratory might be forgiven for feeling spied upon. On the screen of Dr. Takeuchi's computer is a seemingly human face that tries to maintain eye contact with the visitor, tracking him as he moves around the room.

title: Bold New Plan for Imperiled South Pole Station
description: FOR 37 years the United States has continuously operated a scientific station at the South Pole, which has become a world center for research in astrophysics and astronomy, and for monitoring global environmental changes.

title: CLINTON SHUFFLES HIS AIDES, SELECTING BUDGET DIRECTOR AS WHITE HOUSE STAFF CHIEF
description: President Clinton today announced the most extensive staff shake-up of his 17 months in office, redrawing the lines of power in the White House as he searched for a way to give an air of strength and professionalism to his Administration.

title: The Declining Dollar
description: The dollar continued to fall against the German mark yesterday and hovered near a post-World War II low against the Japanese yen. But a lower dollar poses no crisis and, for now, warrants no dramatic attention. Indeed, intervention by Washington is likely to be ineffective or damaging.

title: No Headline
description: "There's something wrong when a teacher can be convicted in a court of law for selling drugs, and the school system can't dismiss him." -- LAWRENCE E. BECKER, director of the New York City Board of Education's Office of Legal Services. [ A1:2. ]

title: The Virtual Actor Makes Its Debut
description: ARTIFICIAL faces have made their theatrical debut, bringing about the age of the virtual actor.

title: Walgreen Co.(WAG,N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Reduced by 3 cents a share in connection with the redemption of $ 100 million of 91/2 percent sinking fund debentures, due in 2016, and after a net charge of $ 23,623,000, or 19 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of two accounting changes.

title: HAITIANS TAKING TO SEA IN DROVES, ALARMING THE U.S.
description: The tide of Haitian boat people surged today to its highest level in more than a year as the Coast Guard picked up more than 1,000 people on the high seas who were seeking to seize the opportunity the Clinton Administration has given them to apply for refugee status.

title: Sanchez Becomes Part of the Upset Crowd
description: Zina Garrison-Jackson provided Wimbledon with its daily upset dose this afternoon on Center Court by spinning an elaborate strategic web around second-seeded Arantxa Sanchez Vicario and eliminating the French Open champion, 7-5, 4-6, 6-3.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9 KURDS' PROSPECTS FADING At the end of the Persian Gulf war, the prospects for a Kurdish state appeared good, but bitter factional fighting has caused hopes of democracy to fade and has dissipated Western support. A1

title: Dow Jumps 48.56 as Dollar Stabilizes
description: Bracing for another sharp decline after a failed central bank intervention in the currency market and political turmoil in Japan, the stock market unexpectedly rallied yesterday as the dollar ended the day nearly unchanged against leading currencies.

title: Robinson to Attend N.B.A. Draft, After All
description: GLENN ROBINSON, expected to be the first pick in the National Basketball Association draft, won't spoil the show after all. Robinson's agent, CHARLES TUCKER, said yesterday that the former Purdue star won't boycott tomorrow's draft at the Hoosier Dome in Indianapolis.

title: Bishop Joseph Durick, 79, Civil Rights Advocate
description: Bishop Joseph Aloysius Durick, who emerged as a strong voice for civil rights in the segregated South despite opposition from his tradition-bound congregation and other members of the clergy, died on Sunday at his home in Bessemer, Ala. He was 79.

title: Moynihal to Push Health Care Plan Paid by Employers
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan will ask the Senate Finance Committee on Tuesday to vote for a national health insurance proposal that would ultimately require employers to pay most of the insurance costs for their workers, a Senate aide said tonight.

title: Clinton Helps Raise Money for Cuomo Campaign
description: Two years ago in Madison Square Garden, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo nominated Bill Clinton as the "Comeback Kid" who could take back the White House for the Democrats. Last night President Clinton returned to New York to return the favor for a threatened Mr. Cuomo, at a brace of fund-raisers intended to help keep a Democratic Governor in one of the biggest statehouses.

title: Biomet Inc.(BMET,NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Wit at the Round Table: Was It, Er, Um, Square?
description: Seventy-five years ago this month -- no one knows the precise date -- the feast of wit known as the Algonquin Round Table got under way.

title: Chiat/Day to Handle Benetton Campaign
description: Chiat/Day was awarded a high-profile creative assignment yesterday, and the agency announced executive changes.

title: On My Mind; Americans on the Golan
description: This is the time for Americans and Israelis to start talking in their own countries about whether American troops should be stationed on the Golan Heights.

title: Ruling Disappoints Cable Executives
description: Both sides claimed some element of victory in yesterday's Supreme Court decision ordering a lower court to reconsider the law that requires cable television systems to carry all of the broadcast stations in their market areas.

title: An Effort to Link Simpson To Hair at Site of Murders
description: After two weeks of talking vaguely about evidence, prosecutors today asked a judge to order O. J. Simpson to provide a hair sample, asserting that a knit cap with "black curly hairs" that were "determined to be of African-American origin" had been found near the body of his slain former wife.

title: Calling All the Leetches: N.H.L. Draft Set to Begin
description: National Hockey League teams today were still scouting players on the eve of the annual entry draft for 17- and 18-year-olds. One target, Jeff O'Neill, said he still had several appointments today with club officials who were preparing for the draft.

title: Stories From A Life
description: As the Lady in Red in "For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/ When the Rainbow Is Enuf," Trazana Beverley proved such a distinctive presence that she won the 1977 Tony Award for best featured actress. Although the theater has never provided her with an equivalent triumph, some of her arresting gifts can be seen in "The Spirit Moves," her one-woman show, which the New Federal Theater is presenting at the Henry Street Settlement through July 17.

title: Amoco to Get $440 Million Tax Refund
description: The Amoco Corporation announced yesterday that it would receive a refund of $440 million from the Internal Revenue Service to settle a long dispute over a tax aimed at limiting windfall profits.

title: Review/Fashion; A 70's Revel for Italian Men's Wear
description: High on a hill in Florence on Friday night, beneath a blood-red moon and on the grounds of one of the city's grandest villas, Ziggy Stardust returned. He had alighted from a hovering spaceship emblazoned with "I (heart) Elvis" and was asking directions to Studio 54.

title: Court's Decisions To Come Thursday
description: The Supreme Court said today that it would announce its next decisions on Thursday, which will be the final day of the 1993-94 term.

title: Interpublic Joins Interactive Venture
description: Time Warner Interactive and the Interpublic Group of Companies said yesterday that they had formed a joint venture to create and produce interactive products like CD-ROM's and interactive television programming. The terms of the agreement, believed to be the first to link an information and entertainment conglomerate and an agency company, were not disclosed.

title: Ruling Leaves Anxiety Among Parents But Perhaps Little Change for Students
description: While the Hasidic villagers of Kiryas Joel were left deeply troubled by their legal setback in the ruling yesterday by the United States Supreme Court, the daily lives of the school district's 200 students may not change that much, school officials said.

title: World Cup Just Might Give U.S. Soccer Fever; Fitba' in Glasgow
description: To the Editor:

title: Jays' Ward to Start Rehabilitation Stint
description: The Toronto Blue Jays relief ace DUANE WARD is heading to Class A Dunedin for a rehabilitation assignment in the Florida State League.

title: Lyrical and Wistful in Songs, A Pop Court Jester Onstage
description: It was stand-up comedy night on Sunday at the Brendan Byrne Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., where Phil Collins performed the second of two consecutive shows. Between songs, Mr. Collins, speaking in a genteel British accent, entertained a near capacity audience of 15,000 with hilarious three-minute monologues about ex-girlfriends, band members and his negligible sex life.

title: Treasury Prices Gain As Commodities Drop
description: Prices of Treasury securities were sharply higher yesterday after rebounding from earlier losses connected to the falling dollar.

title: Corrections
description: The Pulse chart in the Metro Section yesterday included incorrect figures in some editions for the number of lawyers per 100 people in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and the United States. The correct figures are: New York, 0.4 in 1987 and 0.5 in 1993; New Jersey, 0.3 in 1987 and 0.4 in 1993; Connecticut, 0.3 in 1987 and 0.5 in 1993; United States, 0.3 in 1987 and 0.3 in 1993.

title: Lebow to Enter Track Hall of Fame
description: FRED LEBOW, who guided the growth of the New York City Marathon from a low-key race into a major international event, will be inducted into the National Track and Field Hall of Fame next month.

title: Sensitive Spin on Doubleday Pitch
description: His team is in a slump, a few of his veterans are vocally unhappy, and with a possible players' strike looming, the Mets already have suffered from a downswing in attendance.

title: I.B.M. UNIT GETS SUPPORT CONTRACT FROM ALLIED SIGNAL
description: The Integrated Systems Solutions Corporation, a division of I.B.M., said yesterday that it had received a three-year contract from the aerospace unit of Allied Signal Inc. for computer and network support services. Integrated Systems Solutions said it would provide a customer service center for training, technology support and asset management. The agreement will support Allied Signal's operations in Torrance, Calif., and Phoenix. More than 100 Allied Signal employees now performing the work will be offered jobs with Integrated Systems Solutions. Allied Signal, based in Morristown, N.J., makes engines, avionics and other equipment for aircraft and automobiles.

title: A Tournament Record for Being Carded
description: The number of cautions for physical play will most likely reach a record number in this World Cup, but according to FIFA officials, that's just the way they like it.

title: Accounts
description: * Xerox Graphics Systems, Stamford, Conn., to Bradford & Maloney Inc., Greenwich, Conn., as the first agency to handle advertising, public relations and marketing for the new Xerox business unit that manufactures and markets digital film. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Agencies and clients look at each other over a divide marked by tensions and misperceptions.
description: IRRITABLE? Edgy? Got that anxious, uneasy feeling?

title: Hamilton Taft Indictments
description: Two former top executives of Hamilton Taft & Company were indicted today in a payroll tax fraud that cost businesses and nonprofit groups more than $85 million, according to the United States Attorney's office here.

title: Getting Real On Central Europe
description: President Clinton's visits to Latvia and Poland next week, as well as his participation in the Group of Seven summit meeting in Naples a few days later, signal a more comprehensive and strategically coherent U.S. policy toward the former Soviet bloc.

title: SHAKE-UP AT THE WHITE HOUSE: NEWS ANALYSIS Job for a Capital Insider; In Calling on Panetta as Staff Chief, Clinton Opts for a Doer Rather Than a Doorkeeper
description: Marlin Fitzwater, who was the President's spokesman in the Reagan and Bush White Houses, has just finished writing a chapter in his memoirs about the seven chiefs of staff he worked under -- starting and ending with James A. Baker 3d.

title: S.I. President Named By CUNY Trustees
description: Trustees of the City University of New York yesterday named an East Carolina University administrator as the president of the College of Staten Island, replacing a president who was ousted following a feud with the university chancellor.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP OFFERS 175 WORKERS EARLY RETIREMENT
description: The Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that it would offer early retirement benefits to about 175 employees as it pares operations at its headquarters in Camden, N.J. Retirement benefits will be available to employees 55 and older with at least 10 years of service, Campbell said. Employees are to notify the company by Sept. 9, with their effective retirement dates Oct. 1. In the fiscal quarter that ended May 1, Campbell's net income rose 13 percent, to $119 million, or 47 cents a share, compared with the quarter a year earlier.

title: Senate Approves Whitman Budget
description: After a furious last-minute round of political wrangling among the Republican majority, and with Cabinet members looking on anxiously, the Senate today approved the state budget for the 1995 fiscal year.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: RECORDINGS
description: Offering Wagner In an Ultra-Wagnerian Length

title: Big 3 Look at Natural Gas
description: The Big Three auto makers plan to announce on Tuesday that they have formed a research partnership to lower the cost of making vehicles powered by natural gas.

title: Winn Newman, 70; Fought Salary Bias
description: Winn Newman, a labor and civil rights lawyer who fought salary discrimination based on sex or race, died on Friday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 70 and lived in Washington.

title: Keys Emerge To Mystery Of 'Junk' DNA
description: IN recent times, the twisted, viscous molecular celebrity called DNA has been described by any number of lofty metaphors. It is the book of life. The master molecule. The blueprint for a human being.

title: Honors
description: * Allen Dyon, president of the Allstate Motor Club, Arlington Heights, Ill., was named the 1995 chairman of the Direct Marketing Association. Robert M. Edmund, president of Edmund Scientific Co., Barrington, N.J., was named the vice chairman and chairman-elect.

title: Just Married: First Baby Due Today
description: Novell Inc. and the Wordperfect Corporation said yesterday that they had completed their merger and that they would show the first product of the merged companies today at PC Expo in New York.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Gerrity Oil and Gas Inc., Denver, is selling $100 million of senior subordinated notes due in 2004 at 100 to yield 11.75 percent through Morgan Stanley & Co., Dillon, Read & Co. and Paine Webber Inc. The notes are non-callable for five years. After the fifth year, the notes are callable at 105.875 percent, or $1,058.75 for each $1,000, of face value of the notes. The issue is rated B-2 by Moody's Investors Service and B by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CMS ENERGY CORP., Dearborn, Mich., an electricity and natural gas company, said its oil and gas exploration and production unit had paid Sun Company Inc., Philadelphia, a petroleum refinery and oil and gas exploration company, $22.5 million for all the stock of Sun Colombia Co. IMPERIAL OIL LTD., Toronto, said it would eliminate more than 500 jobs, or 25 percent of the work force, at its exploration and production department in Calgary, Alberta, by the end of 1995.

title: Roy Grutman Is Dead at 63; Lawyer for Celebrity Clients
description: Roy Grutman, a trial lawyer whose theatrical panache and mellifluous voice reflected his training as a child actor and helped him defend clients in courts and on television, died on Sunday of liver cancer. He was 63 and lived in Manhattan and Greenwich, Conn.

title: Empire Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $ 95,000 in the quarter and a pretax gain of $ 5,441,000 in the year, both on the sale of properties and investments.c-Included pretax gains of $ 678,000 in the quarter and $ 1,741,000 in the year, both on the sale of properties and investments. The periods were also after losses from discontinued operations of $ 7,451,000, or 22 cents a share, and $ 15,609,000, or 46 cents a share, in the quarter and year, respectively.(Loss)Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Adding Whipped Cream To Bach's 'Coffee' Cantata Cathedral of St. John the Divine

title: Tektronix Inc.(TEK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: b-Net loss, which included $ 150 million restructuring charge in the quarter and year.(Loss)

title: Manor Care Inc.(MNR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included a $ 4.8 million after-tax gain on the sale of property and an adjustment increasing income taxes $ 3.6 million due to a change in the tax law.c-Included extraordinary loss of $ 3,019,000, or 5 cents a share, on debt redemption.

title: Eli Lilly and Somatogen Seek Blood Substitute
description: Eli Lilly & Company entered the race to produce a substitute for human blood yesterday by signing a joint development agreement with Somatogen Inc. of Boulder, Colo.

title: Oklahoma Gas & Electric Co.(OGE,N) reports earnings for 12mos to May 31
description: Oklahoma Gas & Electric's earnings were hindered by the Feb. 25 rate order issued by the Oklahoma Corporation Commission, the company said in a press release. The commission directed Oklahoma Gas & Electric to refund about $ 41 million and to reduce rates by a total of about $ 17 million a year.

title: In a Reversal, Cuomo Will Refund Taxes of Federal Retirees
description: Seeking to end a five-year legal fight that had angered thousands of retirees, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that the state would refund about $60 million to 10,000 retired Federal employees who paid state income taxes that were later deemed unlawful.

title: Patterns
description: Italy Goes Reggae

title: New Strife in Bosnia?
description: Diplomats from the United States, Russia and the European Union will meet here on Tuesday to complete what they regard as a final peace plan for Bosnia, but already it is clear that the Bosnian Government and Croatia are preparing for a coordinated war on the Serbs, not an imminent settlement.

title: GE Capital Canada
description: GE Capital Canada Inc. said today that its commercial real estate group had bought 83 loans and properties from the liquidator of the Standard Trust Company and the Standard Loan Company. The purchase price was not disclosed. GE Capital Canada, a unit of GE Capital, said the properties it had purchased included office buildings, shopping centers, retirement homes and apartments. Ernst & Young was appointed liquidator of Standard Trust and Standard Loan in May 1991 after attempts to sell the companies failed.

title: SHAKE-UP AT THE WHITE HOUSE: CHIEF OF STAFF -- Man in the News; Once at Odds With White House, Now at Its Helm: Leon Edward Panetta
description: Leon E. Panetta, the man now charged with making the White House more efficient and focused, learned early in his career about the power a White House chief of staff can wield.

title: Meriden Mayor Rejects Grants For AIDS Testing and Support
description: Arguing that expanded social services attract poor people and cost cities money, the Mayor of this small city in central Connecticut has rejected state and Federal grants to pay for AIDS testing and counseling at the city's Health Department.

title: U.S. Hopes North Korea Can Be Induced to Extend Nuclear Freeze
description: The Clinton Administration is confident that it will able to verify the freeze on the North Korean nuclear progam in the next round of talks, to begin on July 8. But the big issue is whether the monitoring can be extended after the negotiations.

title: BellSouth Sets Video Trial
description: The BellSouth Corporation will announce on Tuesday a video trial involving more than 10,000 homes in the Atlanta area, people familiar with the project said today.

title: French in Rwanda Discover Thousands of Hutu Refugees
description: It is almost impossible to move through the dirt yard surrounding the Notre Dame Church in this hilltop village, where more than 40,000 Hutu are jammed into an impromptu refugee camp. The crying of children mixes with the sounds of machetes splitting trees in the surrounding hills as men erect more shelters, which are covered with freshly cut greenery.

title: Panel Decision a New Setback In Search for an AIDS Vaccine
description: TEN years ago Margaret M. Heckler, who was then Secretary of Health and Human Services, predicted an AIDS vaccine by 1986. Although the deadline passed, the effort continued.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: POP
description: Two Styles, One Concert, Much Audience Bewilderment Manhattan Center

title: Rudulph Carter, 68, A Former Diplomat
description: Rudulph Ellis Carter, a former Foreign Service officer and a political adviser in the United States Mission to the United Nations, died last Tuesday in Newport Hospital in Rhode Island. A summer resident of Newport, he was 68 and lived in Dallas.

title: Market Place; A shift at the top and perhaps a change in fortunes for L.A. Gear.
description: AFTER a three-year turnaround effort, L.A. Gear is poised to claw its way out of financial ruin, industry executives and analysts say.

title: Moving Money and Awaiting the Fed
description: Steve Dickinson and Mike Clark hunched before a bank of computer screens on the currency-trading floor at Midland Bank's global markets division here today, watching for any sign that the Federal Reserve or the European central banks were stepping in to calm the world's financial markets by halting the sharp slide in the dollar over the last week.

title: Experimental Rocket Lands After Explosion
description: An unmanned experimental rocket that takes off and lands on its tail made an emergency landing in a New Mexico desert today after a mysterious explosion shortly after its engines started, Pentagon officials said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Battered Dollar

title: Invisible People, Made Visible
description: June has been an enlightening, and enlightened, month in New York City. Gotham's citizens could hardly turn on their television sets or ride the subways without encountering some aspect of the astoundingly large gay presence that had converged on the city.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Mayor Applauds Police On Gay March Strategy
description: From a helicopter above Manhattan on Sunday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani watched as the city's Police Department, without an arrest or an injury, managed tens of thousands of people marching toward Central Park -- some of them illegally -- to commemorate the day 25 years ago when that same department had clashed violently with homosexuals at a Greenwich Village bar.

title: Teachers and Tenure: Rights vs. Discipline
description: After Jay Dubner, a special education teacher in New York City, was arrested, convicted and sent to prison in 1990 for selling $7,000 worth of cocaine to undercover police, school officials thought it would be easy to dismiss him.

title: Hebron Is a Bit Quieter, but Certainly Not Peaceful
description: At Hebron's shuttered vegetable market today, two Israeli settlers played paddle-ball and Jewish children rode bicycles outside stalls closed on orders of the Israeli Army.

title: Key in Control As Streak Goes To 11 in a Row
description: Jimmy Key rarely shows any emotion. He smiles about once a week, he frowns at a similar pace and his voice is rarely raised above normal conversational tones. He hardly laughs, he hardly smirks and he hardly shouts. His wife calls him lifeless and he concurs, but does not smile while telling the story. Maybe he will smile next week.

title: CHRONICLE
description: NORMA McCORVEY, the Jane Roe of the landmark Roe v. Wade case that legalized abortion, began work yesterday as a paid counselor at a women's clinic.

title: Bonn Journal; If It's a Museum, Why Does It Look Like an Attic?
description: How the generation of political leaders that runs Germany today views the country's history can now be seen, heard and even touched in a museum that was opened here this month by Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who was 15 in 1945.

title: INSIDE
description: Delay Sought in Sex Suit

title: Beard to Replace Daly as Nets Coach
description: The Nets have called a news conference for today to announce the hiring of Butch Beard, the former Knicks and Nets assistant, to replace Chuck Daly as head coach.

title: By Design; For Bad-Hair Days
description: Summertime can be a succession of bad-hair days, but there are some nifty ways to cope that are decorative as well as camouflaging.

title: Profit and Ego in Data Secrecy
description: If the web of thousands of computer networks around the world can be thought of as an information superhighway, then Jim Bidzos is one of its best-placed toll takers. Mr. Bidzos expects to become very rich -- unless the Government has its way.

title: Clinton's Lawyer Asks for Delay on Sex Harassment Lawsuit
description: Lawyers for President Clinton argued today that he should not be subject to a civil suit while in office and, as a result, that a sexual harassment complaint by a former Arkansas clerical worker should be put off until he leaves the White House.

title: Corrections
description: The weekly Radio Highlights listing on Sunday covered next week's programs, not this week's. Corrected listings are appearing each day in the daily paper.

title: Fernandez Goes on Disabled List
description: Left-hander SID FERNANDEZ was placed on the 15-day disabled list by the Baltimore Orioles yesterday because of a strained rib cage that forced him to miss his last start. The placement is retroactive to June 19. He was replaced by left-hander ARTHUR RHODES, who was recalled from Class AAA Rochester. (AP)

title: Conseco Bid For Kemper Is Accepted
description: The directors of the Kemper Corporation voted unanimously Sunday evening to accept a $3.2 billion purchase offer made Thursday by Conseco Inc., a life insurance company based in Carmel, Ind.

title: Q&A
description: Leonardo's Lengths

title: Bolivia Scores, but Will Still Go Home
description: What began last year at 12,000 feet in La Paz ended on considerably lower ground today for the Bolivians.

title: Mary Drayton; Playwright, 89
description: Mary Drayton, a playwright whose work appeared on Broadway, died on Friday at Sarasota Memorial Hospital in Sarasota, Fla., where she lived. She was 89.

title: Quickly Pedaling His Way Into Legend
description: SOONER or later, Madison beach visitors are sure to spot a white-haired figure in neon spandex dash by on a 14-speed, his empty shirt sleeve flapping against the breeze. That would be Charlie Handy.

title: The Last Shall Be First And the Fans Love It
description: Let's try to figure this out: The Mets, after their 9-8 loss to St. Louis at Shea Stadium last night, are nine games under .500. The Texas Rangers are seven games under .500. But the Mets are in last place, and the Rangers are in first place. The Mets are so far from first they have no chance to reach the post-season playoffs. The Rangers could reach them by winning a division championship.

title: I.B.M. PowerPC Timetable
description: I.B.M. said today that it would start selling personal computers based on PowerPC chips in the fourth quarter, later than some analysts had expected.

title: MACY REPORTS SOME INCOME IMPROVEMENT IN MAY
description: R. H. Macy & Company, laboring to emerge from bankruptcy protection early next year, reported yesterday that its losses shrank in May, thanks to tight inventory management that prevented markdowns. While sales slipped 4.4 percent last month, to $452 million, the retailer managed to eke out operating income of $6.4 million, compared with an operating loss of $7.4 million in the corresponding month last year. While analysts are generally pleased with Macy's continuing ability to reduce expenses, the company's slipping sales are still a concern. Adjusted for closed stores and the elimination of much of the company's consumer electronics business, sales in stores open at least one year increased a scant half percent.

title: A Shakeup in Women's Singles
description: Whoever thought Zina Garrison-Jackson and Lori McNeil would save women's tennis?

title: Divorced Father Accused Of Killing His 2 Children
description: A 50-year-old divorced father, apparently distraught that his former wife and two children were moving to Florida, murdered the children Sunday and then drove with the bodies to the police headquarters here and parked, the authorities said today.

title: Small Agency's Fate In Doubt After Split
description: The principals of Baron & Zaretsky, a small agency in New York, said yesterday that they had separated and were considering the fate of the shop, which has lost several clients recently.

title: Justices Back Cable Regulation
description: A deeply divided Supreme Court endorsed a broad framework for Federal regulation of cable television today but stopped just short of upholding the 1992 law that requires cable systems to retransmit the signals of local broadcasters.

title: Software Puts Meals And More On a Menu
description: THE city is London, the time is almost 6 P.M., and the immediate question is, what about dinner? Out comes the Newton Messagepad.

title: Same Roots Nourish Russia and Ukraine
description: To the Editor:

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: Ethan Stiefel's OberonIn 'Midsummer Night's Dream' New York State Theater

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: First Impressions Presented By the North/South Troupe Merce Cunningham Studio

title: SHAKE-UP AT THE WHITE HOUSE: BUDGET DIRECTOR Woman in the News; A Hawk on Budgets -- Alice Mitchell Rivlin
description: Many young Americans dream of becoming President someday, but Alice M. Rivlin had a different dream: to become director of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: Study Criticizes Subsidy For Insurance for Poor
description: A new study finds serious, unsuspected problems with many proposals for the Federal Government to help low-income people buy private health insurance by subsidizing their premiums.

title: WNET Considers Closing Manhattan Production Studio
description: WNET, Channel 13, New York's premier public television station, is considering closing its production studio to save money.

title: Energy Secretary Tells a Few More U.S. Nuclear Secrets
description: Opening the door to American nuclear secrets a little wider, Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary today gave fuller details about the atomic tests and radiation experiments of the cold war era.

title: TENNECO TO SELL ITS AUTOMOTIVE BRAKE DIVISION
description: Tenneco Inc.'s automotive parts subsidiary said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its brake division to focus on more profitable vehicle parts. Terms of the transaction between Tenneco Automotive and James E. Bennett Jr. of Charleston, S.C., were not disclosed. Tenneco Brake manufactures brake friction products for the automotive and heavy-duty markets, and sells a broad line of brake components and accessories. The brake division produced $54 million of Tenneco Automotive's $1.8 billion in revenue in 1993. Tenneco Inc. had total revenues of $13.3 billion last year. Mr. Bennett is forming a new corporation to acquire the brake unit.

title: World Cup Just Might Give U.S. Soccer Fever
description: To the Editor:

title: Ameron Inc.(AMN,N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Ameron said that the year-ago quarter and six months included substantial equity in earnings of affiliated companies and significant income from large fiberglass pipe projects in North Africa that ended in the fourth quarter last year.The company also said that 1993 second quarter net income without equity income was 92 cents a share, and the six months net income in 1993 without equity income was 84 cents a share.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When EDWARD F. ARRIGONI walked into the Water Club on the East River the other evening, the 150 guests who had come expecting to celebrate his 60th birthday, shouted, "Surprise!"

title: Immigration Magnet; The Lower East Side Changes Its Face
description: The rabbi, a portrait of gentle authority with his long silk overcoat and silvery beard, sits in a study of burled-wood bookshelves filled with large volumes on rabbinical law and gestures backward, indicating that there is not just one telephone in his office, but two.

title: Miscellany
description: * Cowles Business Media, Stamford, Conn., has agreed to acquire the Wells Group, Minneapolis, a custom publishing and marketing company. The terms were not disclosed.

title: Finlay Fine Jewelry Corp. reports earnings for 13wks to Apr 30
description: b-Included LIFO method which had the effect of decreasing income of $ 178,000.

title: Chess
description: The greatest number of games won outright in the world championship quarterfinals of the Professional Chess Association occurred in the match between Michael Adams of England and Sergei Tiviakov of Russia.

title: Artisoft
description: Artisoft Inc., a Tucson, Ariz., software developer, saw its stock price rise sharply yesterday after it began shipping French, Italian, German and other versions of its Lantastic network operating system. Such networks allow computers to share printers and other devices. Artisoft products are popular with small businesses.

title: Acer to Sell Stakes in Units
description: Acer Inc. will sell majority stakes in 21 businesses by the end of the decade in an effort to focus on individual business segments.

title: Jewel Thief In 7 Robberies Strikes Again In Manhattan
description: A dapper jewel thief brandishing a silver automatic pistol, who the police say was involved in seven other robberies in Manhattan that netted more than $500,000 in diamond rings and precious bracelets and left three victims wounded, struck again over the weekend, detectives said yesterday.

title: Implant Study Too Small for Final Word
description: To the Editor:

title: Franco Squanders An Epic Comeback
description: It could have been the big breakthrough moment the Mets had been hoping -- no, begging -- to see. Mired in a slump, criticized by their manager, frustratingly weak at the plate, the Mets staged a marvelous comeback last night at Shea Stadium, a one-inning bonanza that took them from a six-run deficit to a one-run lead over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Now, Focus the President
description: Yesterday's staff shake-up at the White House was overdue. Things have not been working. Apart from the managerial foul-ups that have plagued this Administration from day one, the White House has not yet conveyed clear messages on foreign policy and even some domestic issues. With health care approaching the moment of truth on Capitol Hill, and with Mr. Clinton about to embark on a trip to Europe where his diplomatic credentials are suspect, there was a clear need for change.

title: One Era Ends, One Resumes In the Harbor
description: Some people saw their ship come in yesterday; others saw it go out.

title: Accused Mother Has Multiple Personalities, Family Says
description: Karisa Santiago, the 21-year-old Yonkers woman accused of killing one of her three children who died mysteriously last year, has what appears to be multiple-personality disorder, family members said today.

title: The Case of jpmorgan
description: To the Editor:

title: A Year Later, Snag Persists In Math Proof
description: ONE year ago, a shy and somewhat secretivemathematician stunned the world by announcing that he had proved Fermat's last theorem, the most famous unsolved problem in mathematics. Yet a year later, he still has not published his proof. Was the claim premature?

title: Death on the World Cup Express
description: The Group of Death has reached its final reckoning. Today is the day.

title: Coffee Futures Soar 25%, Biggest Daily Rise in 7 Years
description: Coffee prices surged more than 25 percent yesterday, the largest one-day rise in more than seven years, as a damaging frost struck much of the coffee-growing areas of Brazil.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In January 1990, in an apartment owned by YOKO ONO in the Dakota, Keith Haring did his first religious artwork, a triptych entitled "The Life of Christ," which he carved into clay and had cast in bronze covered in white gold. A month later he died, and the huge piece -- 5 feet by 10 feet -- went into storage.

title: G.M. Expected to Name North American Chief
description: The General Motors Corporation plans to announce on Tuesday the promotion of G. Richard Wagoner Jr., now the chief financial officer and head of worldwide purchasing, to run the company's crucial North American automotive operations, G.M. officials said today.

title: Observer; Activism Epidemic!
description: In May I became aware of the disturbing new ism that is loose in America. It is activism.

title: Haiti's Strongman Reported Ready to Retire in October
description: Haiti's military strongman has said he will step down when his term as commander of the Haitian armed forces expires in October, a high-level military officer said today.

title: F.B.I. Seeks German Help on Lopez
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has asked the German Justice Ministry for assistance in investigating General Motors' assertions that a former executive, Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, committed industrial espionage when he jumped to Volkswagen A.G. in 1993, a ministry official said today.

title: Let's Not 'Treat' the Problem of Homelessness With Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Britten's Music Festival Revives Under a Three-Headed Regime
description: At 9:15 this morning, Sheila Colvin and her box-office staff broke out a bottle of Champagne. Ticket sales through Friday night, two days before the end of this year's Aldeburgh Festival, had met the projected figure, meaning that the budget would be in the black.

title: Parasites Amid the Useful 'Junk'
description: FOR all the new insights researchers are gathering into the usefulness of the abundant genetic material in the cell that had long been dismissed as molecular junk, they have also learned that at least some portion of human DNA does not serve its host any good, and may on occasion do real harm.

title: Corrections
description: A sports caption in some editions on Friday with a picture by Reuters showing the Italian soccer star Roberto Baggio misstated the timing of his removal from the match. It happened later than the scene shown.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Courville Takes Lead in Long Island Jerry Courville Jr. of Shore Haven, winner of the title in 1990 and '91, shot a one-over-par 72 yesterday for the first-round lead in the Metropolitan Golf Association/Met Life Ike Tournament at Bethpage State Park Black Course, Farmingdale, L.I. A field of 108 competed in the stroke play championship. The cut was 79, with 40 advancing to today's final 36 holes. Courville also has won the team title four times, three with his father, who is not playing because of chemotherapy treatment for cancer. The 35-year-old Courville three-putted two holes on the front nine, where he finished one under at 35. Jeff Thomas of Plainfield West, the 1993 M.G.A. Player of the Year, failed to make it with an 80.

title: Runoff Seems Likely In Ukrainian Vote; Count Moves Slowly
description: President Leonid M. Kravchuk and his former Prime Minister, Leonid D. Kuchma, seemed headed today for a runoff vote in Ukraine's presidential elections, which displayed a country deeply split between east and west.

title: Big Board Seat: $830,000
description: A seat on the New York Stock Exchange has been sold for $830,000, unchanged from the previous seat sale on March 17, the exchange said yesterday. The current bid for a seat on the exchange is $725,000, and the offering price is $1.1 million.

title: Quarrels of Kurdish Leaders Sour Dreams of a Homeland
description: After the Persian Gulf war, with much of the world moved to pity by their plight, the Kurds of northern Iraq seemed poised to realize the ancient Kurdish dream of freedom.

title: Dollar Falls But Rallies Some at End
description: The dollar hit another record low against the Japanese yen in Tokyo early today but later bounced back in New York, buoyed by falling commodity prices, a rising bond market and a new sense among some investors that the weak dollar is a bigger problem for Japan than it is for the United States.

title: Cable TV Ruling
description: The Supreme Court, in a 5-4 decision, endorsed a broad framework for Federal regulation of cable TV but stopped short of upholding the law requiring cable systems to retransmit the signals of local broadcasters.

title: BE Aerospace Inc.(BEAV,NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
The Constitution's New Public Burden
description: The Supreme Court has laid a heavy new burden on governments trying to regulate land use in the public interest. Chief Justice William Rehnquist's opinion for a narrow 5-to-4 majority was a triumph of ideology over community needs to protect fragile environments and scarce resources.

title: Charles Moertel, 66; Studied Treatment And Cost of Cancer
description: Dr. Charles Moertel, a cancer researcher at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., died on Monday at his home. He was 66 and lived in Rochester.

title: Phar-Mor Seeks Time
description: Phar-Mor Inc. said today that it had filed a motion with the United States Bankruptcy Court to extend its exclusive period for filing a reorganization plan with the court by 30 days. The motion is supported by the company's bank and insurance creditors and the official committee for the uninsured creditors. Phar-Mor's exclusivity period expires Thursday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Gibstein Breaks From Pack and Wins With a 69 in the afternoon round yesterday at the Black Course at Bethpage (L.I.) State Park, Ed Gibstein of the Engineers Club not only captured the Metropolitan Golf Association's Met Life/Ike Championship but also deprived the Courville family of another feather in its cap. The 35-year-old Gibstein's two-under-par closing round enabled him to break away from the pack and gave him a three-over total of 216 for the three-round event. That was five strokes better than Jerry Courville Jr. of Shore Haven, who won the tournament twice and whose father won it six times.

title: U.S. Seeks New Process Sites For Wave of Fleeing Haitians
description: Fearing that its centers for processing fleeing Haitians will soon be overwhelmed, the Clinton Administration tried today to find additional interview sites as Coast Guard vessels picked up more than 600 Haitians trying to leave the country.

title: New York Holds Domestic-Violence Hearings
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Western Utilities In Agreement to Merge
description: Two Western electric and gas utilities, the Washington Water Power Company of Spokane, Wash., and Sierra Pacific Resources of Reno, said today that they had agreed to merge in an effort to remain more competitive in an industry undergoing fundamental change.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Friday, about marketing to lesbians and gay men, misstated the size of a mailing that the AT&T Corporation aimed at gay consumers to promote its long-distance telephone services. It was 70,000 pieces of mail, not more than a million.

title: MacTavish Will Reportedly Coach Oilers
description: CRAIG MacTAVISH, a late-season addition to the Stanley Cup champion Rangers, will retire as a player to replace GLEN SATHER as head coach of the Edmonton Oilers, according to a published report. The New York Post said yesterday that MacTavish, acquired from Edmonton on March 31, would rejoin the Oilers soon after July 1. (AP)

title: Beard Quietly Takes Over Nets' Helm
description: For years, sitting on the sidelines as a player and an assistant coach, he was preparing himself for this moment. Even when he was appointed head coach at Howard University in 1990, he was aiming for this opportunity.

title: Ratify the Chemical Arms Ban
description: The Senate will vote next month on a global treaty to ban chemical weapons, which could substantially reduce the chances that U.S. troops will ever face a chemically-armed foe. Opponents would prefer to keep chemical arms to deter the use of gas by others. And a recent revelation that Russia may be concealing efforts to develop advanced chemical weapons has fueled doubts about Washington's ability to verify compliance.

title: Treasury Prices Tumble; Variety of Factors Cited
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday, buffeted by another retreat in the dollar, a surge in commodity prices, bearish economic news and concern about the next interest-rate rise by the Federal Reserve.

title: Calm, Collected Katie Beers Testifies in Sex Abuse Case
description: For months, prosecutors had prepared for this day, first trying to avoid it entirely and then getting their young witness ready with a dress rehearsal in the courtroom and a luncheon with the judge.

title: Higher Taxes? No Problem. Voters Rescue School.
description: A white elephant of a building mixing turn-of-the-century French, Flemish and Tudor Revival styles, Fairhaven High School, known locally as the Castle, is not your conventional schoolhouse.

title: U.S. Force Ready to Take Last Aides From Somalia
description: With fighting among clans increasing in Somalia, the Pentagon has sent an amphibious force of 2,000 marines to the area to evacuate the small American diplomatic contingent in Mogadishu if necessary.

title: Stocks Lose Ground, With Dow Off 15.86
description: Old worries piled on the new worry of the declining dollar yesterday as the stock market retreated slightly after a one-day rally.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Daimler Getting New Chairman
description: Daimler-Benz A.G., Germany's largest industrial concern, is expected on Wednesday to name Jurgen E. Schrempp, the head of its aerospace division, as the next chairman of the managing board.

title:
WORLD CUP '94;
History Is Made: 1 Russian, 5 Goals
description: Oleg Salenko joined Russia's national team in time for its final World Cup qualifying game last October and only eight months later he is playing in his first World Cup. Today the 24-year-old striker from Leningrad did something that has never been done in 15 World Cup tournaments.

title: It Wouldn't Be Summer Without Salade Nicoise
description: PERHAPS the most famous one-dish summer meal is salade nicoise -- the happy combination of tuna, green beans, potatoes and tomatoes in a zesty dressing with anchovies and capers.

title: Milton E. Mermelstein; Lawyer, 86
description: Milton E. Mermelstein, a Manhattan lawyer for 50 years and a former chairman of Alexander's Department Stores Inc., died on June 21 at his home in Deal, N.J. He was 86.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Mr. Jenkins adds a twist to a new campaign for Tanqueray gin.
description: MR. CLEAN, Mr. Salty, Mr. Whipple, Mr. Peanut, Mr. Bubble -- and Mr. Jenkins.

title: Blackmun Has Acted On the Death Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: Fairest Way to Pay for Health Plan Is by Taxes; Cap Insurers' Share
description: To the Editor:

title: Studies Show Small Companies Play Big Role
description: New York has long been identified with the Fortune 500 corporate giants whose names adorn Manhattan skyscrapers or that are based in suburban office complexes around the metropolitan area.

title: Fashion Post Is Dropped At Bergdorf
description: In a move that caused jaws to drop along Seventh Avenue, Bergdorf Goodman, the elegant store that is a destination for connoisseurs of designer fashion, abruptly eliminated the position of fashion director and put Ellin Saltzman out of a job.

title: Boy Killed In Baseball Mishap
description: A 12-year-old boy taking batting practice with his Little League team in Brooklyn was killed yesterday by a baseball fired from a pitching machine, the police said.

title: Market Place; Two insurers of mortgages may take rising interest rates in stride.
description: INVESTORS are so nervous about rising interest rates that they are not thinking clearly about how different financial service companies are affected, according to some analysts. Take the difference between companies that lend money to home buyers and those that sell insurance policies guaranteeing that such mortgages will be paid.

title: Requests by Charities Overwhelm Restaurants
description: LIKE a benevolent urban stroller who has been confronted by one too many mendicants, restaurants and related businesses across the country are balking at the overwhelming number of requests they receive from charities for free meals and services.

title: Hospital Chain Sets Guilty Plea
description: National Medical Enterprises Inc., one of the nation's largest psychiatric hospital chains, said today that it would plead guilty to paying kickbacks and bribes for referrals, even as a former executive admitted to arranging $20 million to $40 million in illegal payments -- and then scheming to get Medicare reimbursement.

title: Denizens of the Nightclubs Venture Into the Daylight
description: The first of the JVC Jazz Festival's free outdoor concerts brought five groups and five hours of music to Damrosch Park on Sunday afternoon. Most of the concert was like a sampler of average nights at mid-level jazz clubs, minus the cover and minimum.

title: INSIDE
description: A Bold Simpson Defense

title: Universal Coverage. It's Now or Never.
description: Alone in the industrialized world, the typical American family must worry that medical bills could bankrupt it some day, or that a stricken parent, son or daughter could go without needed care. That nightmare haunts not only the millions of Americans who are uninsured, it should worry anyone whose insurance coverage comes with a job that may be lost.

title: On Wiggles Of War And Bodies Building
description: Pilobolus Dance Theater has tumbled, wiggled and squirmed its way back to the Joyce Theater. The gymnastically oriented company opened a five-week season there on Monday night and looked as perky as ever. And just as it has often done in the past, it raised serious questions about dance composition while it entertained.

title: Dining as the Nation's Founders Did
description: When it opened more than 200 years ago, City Tavern was Le Cirque of Philadelphia. Started by a group of 53 prominent investors, including Lieut. Gov. John Penn and several signers of the Declaration of Independence, it was decidedly clubby and, as John Adams wrote, created suppers "as elegant as was ever laid on a table." Some meetings of the Second Continental Congress were held there, as were more raucous gatherings where prodigious quantities of alcohol were consumed.

title: School Guard Is Charged With Statutory Rape of Student
description: In a case that raises further questions about the quality of the safety force in New York City public schools, a security guard who was being investigated for dating a teen-ager was arrested late Monday on charges of having sex with a 12-year-old student.

title: Sweden Settles for a Tie With Brazil
description: After one half, it appeared the United States soccer team just might have its very important date with Sweden instead of Brazil. But that was before Romario, the gifted and volatile forward, struck with his customary swiftness.

title: Another Good Church-State Lesson
description: The Supreme Court has reaffirmed, with refreshing clarity, the historic barrier that the First Amendment demands against impermissible state aid to religion. By a 6-to-3 vote the Court struck down as unconstitutional the creation of a special school district for Satmar Hasidic residents of a town 50 miles northwest of New York City.

title: Personal Health
description: POOLS are great fun, terrific for cooling down on a hot day and for getting aerobic exercise. But they are are also a responsibility. As residential pools have proliferated, so, unfortunately, has the opportunity for tragedy.

title: No Mattingly, But 10-0 Run Lifts Spirits
description: The telephone rang at 10 A.M. in Buck Showalter's hotel room today and the distressing news took roughly 10 seconds for him to digest. Don Mattingly told the manager that his right wrist was very sore. Two hours later, Mattingly was on an airplane flying back to New York to be examined by a hand specialist.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: SUMMER You know it's summer When a beach ball Rolls by itself Out of the garage, Jumps up in your lap, A red-yellow moon, Holding its breath For the inevitable volley, Spike, roll in the sand, Dip in the ocean, Kick in the head. ERNEST SLYMAN . . .

title: FILM REVIEW: I Love Trouble; Nick Nolte and Julia Roberts As Crime-Fighting Rival Reporters
description: As a veteran Chicago reporter named Peter Brackett, Nick Nolte glares down at his computer keyboard. Floating over the letters, covering the keys one by one until the whole alphabet vanishes, is row after row of Julia Roberts's face. She is Sabrina Peterson, his chief crosstown rival, and during her first few days on the job she has written enough front-page stories to get her picture on the side of the Chicago Globe's delivery trucks. Of course, Brackett has a head start in the fame department. He already has his picture on the Chicago Chronicle's trucks, and his face on a Gap ad on a bus shelter. Don't go to "I Love Trouble" looking for realism.

title: D.M.B.& B. Chosen For Lockheed Job
description: The Lockheed Corporation said yesterday that it had selected the Los Angeles office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles to handle its account, which had been at McCann-Erickson Los Angeles for the last 29 years. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Arts Cuts Are Sought In Senate
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended yesterday that the $170.2 million budget of the National Endowment for the Arts be cut by 5 percent in the next fiscal year. The recommendation came as part of the committee's final drafting of an appropriations bill for the Department of the Interior and related agencies.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED IN ALBANY TO CURB PAY-PHONE RATES
description: New York State legislative leaders announced agreement today on a bill that for the first time would limit certain rates on pay telephones owned by small private companies, which often charge high prices and surcharges to unsuspecting customers.

title: Seeking Solace and Support in Meditation Books
description: Pressed for time and hungry for solace, many Americans are seeking spiritual nurture and serenity in small "meditation books" that are proliferating in the inspiration and self-help sections of the nation's bookstores.

title: Dollar Again Falls Below 100-Yen Level
description: The dollar fell to another record low against the Japanese yen in Asian trading today.

title: Mansell to Drive in French Grand Prix
description: he former world champion NIGEL MANSELL will return to Formula One for this weekend's French Grand Prix. The Williams-Renault team announced yesterday in England that Mansell will compete in Sunday's race in what the 1992 world champion said was a guest appearance. Williams has tried to get Mansell to return from Indy-car racing since Ayrton Senna's death in the San Marino Grand Prix on May 1. (AP)

title: First Bid Deadline Passes For Madison Square Garden
description: First bids were due yesterday for Madison Square Garden, its sports teams and its cable television sports network. Allen & Company, the investment bankers handling the sale for the Garden's new owner, Viacom Inc., sent out detailed financial data on the assets to approximately 40 possible bidders.

title: Barkley Will Return Despite Back Injury
description: CHARLES BARKLEY, who frequently hinted at retirement while leading the Phoenix Suns to the National Basketball Association playoffs last season, said yesterday that he would return for another shot at the championship despite a back injury.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday, about a turnaround effort by L.A. Gear Inc., misstated the surname of a former president of the company in some editions. He is Mark R. Goldston, not Gladston.

title: Fairest Way to Pay for Health Plan Is by Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Virginia's Candidates for Senate Debate, Making Cases to Tough Audience of Voters
description: In a lively free-for-all on worldwide television tonight, the four candidates running for the United States Senate from Virginia clashed in their first joint debate over issues like character, crime and foreign policy.

title: SALE OF SOME HOOK-SUPERX STORES IS DISCUSSED BY REVCO
description: Revco D.S. Inc. said yesterday that it was negotiating with Federal regulators about the possibility of selling some Hook-Superx Inc. stores so that its acquisition of the drugstore chain would meet antitrust standards. Revco, based in Twinsburg, Ohio, said in April that it had reached an agreement to buy Hook-Superx, based in Cincinnati, for $13.75 a share, or about $600 million. Revco's general counsel, Jack Staph, said the Federal Trade Commission had raised the issue of selling stores in some regions. "We're in negotiations on it," he said. An F.T.C. spokesman said he could not comment on the case. Revco and Hook-Superx each operate about 1,200 stores. The acquisition would create the second-biggest drugstore chain, behind Rite Aid.

title: Jews Revisit Shanghai, Grateful Still That It Sheltered Them
description: They stood in the pouring rain not long ago, a few dozen Jews from all over the world and their Communist Chinese hosts, to commemorate Shanghai's role as a safe haven for Jewish refugees fleeing the Holocaust.

title: China Migrants: Economic Engine, Social Burden
description: With his possessions bundled in plastic and hung from his shoulders, and his trousers rolled up to beat the heat, 30-year-old Ren Jun drifted into Beijing this month, part of a migrant tide of 50 million peasants that is threatening to swamp China's urban landscape.

title: Qaddafi Foe May Be Alive
description: The wife of a Libyan opposition figure who disappeared in Egypt six months ago says she was told by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in a meeting last week in Libya that her husband was alive.

title: Gay Games Add Vistas For Couple
description: CATHERINE Hughes and Jane Morrigan should have got back by now to their Nova Scotia farm after the 24-hour drive from New York. They probably will already have hung up the bronze medal that Ms. Hughes won in the 1,500-meter race at the Gay Games, and the one Ms. Morrigan received for singing with the gay and lesbian chorus during their week in New York.

title: Grim View From Brazil Coffee Fields
description: Wanderley Cintra Ferreira, president of the coffee growers cooperative of Franca, in the interior of Sao Paulo state, flew over the cooperative's blighted coffee fields today, to survey the damage from Brazil's worst cold snap in nearly 20 years.

title: Wine Talk
description: Last fall, the French news magazine L'Express reported that varietal wines -- wines identified by the grape they are made from -- were sweeping the world. It was an unstoppable trend, L'Express said, and France had better get with it.

title: In Bosnia's Other War, Truce Can't Overcome Distrust
description: The spindly, olive-skinned children begging truck drivers for money at a front-line checkpoint and the watchful woman in a grimy yellow scarf at the roadside augur well for this city, divided and half demolished in Muslim-Croatian warfare, locals say.

title: Mexico Thrives In 'Group Of Death'
description: Add another surprise to the list of surprises in this 15th World Cup: Mexico, champions of Group E.

title: Cuban Tells Of Cinema Troubles
description: The director of the Havana Film Festival, for years a showcase of Cuban culture and a test of Communist tolerance, has left Cuba and vowed not to return, saying he will seek political asylum in the United States because he fears a new wave of repression against Cuban artists.

title: Compromise Is Proposed On H.I.V. Test
description: Derailing a proposal to force doctors to inform parents if their newborns test positive for H.I.V. antibodies, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver has put his substantial clout behind a compromise that would instead require doctors to counsel pregnant women and new mothers to take the tests themselves.

title: Agency Issues New Guidelines For Managing Heart Conditions
description: Millions of people suffering from progressive heart failure can live longer and do more if they comply better with recommended treatments and if their doctors are more aggressive in prescribing cardiac medications, Federal health officials said today.

title: Defection Means New Tactics, Lawyers in Bomb Case Say
description: Defense lawyers representing the men charged with plotting to bomb New York City landmarks charged yesterday that the defection of a key defendant to the prosecution's side could hurt them because of how well the defector knows their strategies.

title: U.S. Wins Without Playing: It's On to the Second Round
description: The United States achieved its first goal of the World Cup today, advancing to the second round of play against one of the tournament favorites, Brazil. The two teams will play next Monday afternoon -- the Fourth of July -- in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Thompson Promotes Two Top Executives
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company has promoted two top executives to the additional new positions of worldwide creative directors. They are Jim Patterson, 47, the chairman and chief creative officer of Thompson North America in New York, who also serves as executive creative director of Thompson's New York office, and Allen Thomas, 49, the chairman and chief creative officer of Thompson Europe in London. The appointments were made yesterday by Burt Manning, the chairman and chief executive of Thompson, who was the agency's last worldwide creative director, from 1978 to 1980.

title: FOUNDATION HEALTH TO BUY H.M.O. IN FLORIDA
description: Consolidation in the health care industry continued yesterday, as the Foundation Health Corporation, based in Rancho Cordova, Calif., said it would buy CareFlorida Health Systems Inc. for $250 million in stock. Foundation Health, a health maintenance organization with 527,000 members, will use the acquisition of privately held CareFlorida to expand into Florida, one of the fastest-growing markets for managed care. CareFlorida, based in Miami, is also an H.M.O. The transaction will dilute Foundation Health's earnings by about 5 percent this year, the company said. But it said the acquisition should lead to added earnings within 12 to 18 months after the expected closing on Oct. 1. Shares of Foundation Health closed up 37.5 cents, to $38.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Graf to Compete in Pathmark Event
description: STEFFI GRAF, the world's top-ranked woman, announced yesterday that she would once again play in the Pathmark Classic in Mahwah, N.J., after a three-year absence.

title: To Raise the Performance Of Minorities, a College Increased Its Standards
description: As educators around the country debate how best to raise the achievement of minority students in mathematics and science, no one has to persuade the engineers at Georgia Institute of Technology that success lies in expecting more from students, not less.

title: At G.M., the Guard Changes But the Strategy Remains
description: The General Motors Corporation today announced a raft of retirements and promotions aimed at cementing the turnaround of its core North American automotive operations and stimulating its sales internationally.

title: EXXON UNIT TO CUT 430 JOBS IN A REVAMPING
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it would cut 430 jobs in its domestic production subsidiary, or 2.8 percent of the unit's work force. The company said it would take a charge on the cutbacks, but declined to disclose the amount or when it would be taken. "Exxon will take an appropriate charge, but the amount will be immaterial to Exxon's results," a spokesman for the company said. The job cuts by the Exxon Company U.S.A., based in Houston, are part of a revamping of the unit. The company said it would consolidate some production division activities in Houston from offices in Thousand Oaks, Calif., New Orleans and Midland, Tex.

title: House Easily Approves Communications Bills
description: The House of Representatives today overwhelmingly approved a sweeping package of legislation to rewrite the nation's telecommunications laws, but heated debates are still expected when the Senate takes up a similar measure next month.

title: Sabi Sand Journal; Trying to Bridge South Africa's Rich-Poor Chasm
description: The worlds on either side of the wire fence that surrounds this mammoth private game reserve could not be more different from each other.

title: Hinting at More Changes, Panetta Takes the Reins
description: The capital was witness to a ritual guard-changing today as a freshly minted White House chief of staff visited subordinates, journalists and television hosts to proclaim that he was ready to make the White House work for the President again.

title: 2 KOREAS SET DATE FOR FIRST MEETING OF THEIR LEADERS
description: North and South Korea agreed today to a three-day summit meeting starting on July 25 in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital. It would be the first meeting of the top leaders of the two countries since the Korean Peninsula was divided in 1945.

title: In America; Wives And Batterers
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, speaking about family violence at a breakfast in midtown Manhattan yesterday, made a startling comparison.

title: Norway Odd Team Out of Race
description: In the end, when Norwegians and the Irishmen combined to grasp Irish flags on the grass of Giants Stadium, the total of 4 points was not the most important statistic in Norway's first finals appearance in 56 years.

title: Reed, at Crossroads, Chooses Beard's Pat
description: Alfred (Butch) Beard is Willis Reed's man. It is a pretty fair assumption that no one above Reed in the Nets' organization would have thought of Beard to replace Chuck Daly, much less hired him. You might say that Reed, criticized in recent years for being too much a company front man, is sticking his neck out, hiring an undistinguished college coach at a time when his team, and by extension his career, is at the crossroads.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: How Kansas City Attacks The Problem of Murder
description: Tonight it's K.C.P.D. Blue on ABC, as "Turning Point" turns its cameras on members of the Kansas City Murder Squad going about the workaday routine of tracking down perps.

title: INTEGRA TO ACQUIRE LINCOLN SAVINGS FOR $52.2 MILLION
description: The Integra Financial Corporation of Pittsburgh signed a definitive agreement yesterday to acquire Lincoln Savings Bank of Carnegie, Pa., for $52.2 million in cash. Lincoln Savings has $250 million in assets and seven branches in two western Pennsylvania counties. Integra, which has assets of $13.9 billion and 258 offices in 22 counties near Pittsburgh, said it would pay $58 a share for the 900,000 shares of Lincoln Savings. Integra already owns about 45,000 shares of the savings bank. Shares of Lincoln jumped $3.875, to $54.375, on Nasdaq, while shares of Integra rose 25 cents, to $47, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Streisand Tickets Prove Mixed Blessing for Charities
description: Barbra Streisand set aside 4,000 tickets to her Madison Square Garden shows for select nonprofit organizations to sell for $1,000 apiece. Yet many of those agencies, despite hiring extra staff and working overtime, found themselves unable to sell all the tickets allotted to them.

title: Executive of Bates Quits After Dispute
